speakeroldname: Mr. McDermid (for the Minister of Finance) moved
speechtext:
that the bill be read the third time and passed.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak on third and final reading on Bill C-61, the borrowing authority bill.
Let me begin by putting this legislation in its proper context. That of course is the context of the budget that was presented a few weeks ago by the Minister of Finance, a budget that cuts government spending, cuts taxes, cuts the deficit, bolsters economic recovery and strengthens the international competitiveness of our economy.
Any debate on borrowing authority has to address the issue of public debt and deficit, burdens that weigh heavily on the people of Canada and that constrain the capabilities of the government.
There is one important and fundamental lesson governments everywhere have learned from recent recessions. That is never again must government allow itself to be financially crippled by debt.
The Liberals sit here and laugh at that. They sit there and they laugh. They laugh at government being crippled by debt. They left this government with a $200 billion debt. Canadians have been paying for that ever since.
Governments cannot assist those facing hardship or stimulate economies with money they do not have. To try to do so by borrowing more would only lead to higher deficits, higher debt, higher interest rates, slower growth and all that. It is not a pretty picture, as we know.
Renewed effort to reduce the deficit was one of the things Canadians clearly told us they expected from this budget. In all the pre-budget consultations that the Minister of Finance, myself, and the President of the Treasury Board had across Canada, that was the one message that came from every group no matter what
March 23, 1992

their status in our society, that we must reduce the deficit. They also wanted realistic and lasting solutions to our economic problems, streamlined government to meet the realities of the 1990s, new opportunities for people to improve their skills and knowledge.
The government has responded to these challenges with a budget that takes action to bolster recovery this year and strengthen growth and job creation in the years ahead.
The budget provides help where help is needed, but it pays for that help not by increasing taxes or increasing the deficit, but by reducing expenditures; not by increasing borrowing and taxes. It cuts spending to reduce taxes and bolster economic growth and competitiveness. The budget also ensures significant declines in the deficit for 1992-93 and the following years.
The deficit will be held to $31.4 billion in the 1991-92 fiscal year which ends in about a week. It will be reduced by almost $4 billion to $27.5 billion next year and to $22.5 billion in 1993-94.
Nobody believes that.

The hon. member for Kingston and the Islands is sitting over there delivering his speech from the seat of his pants. I understand that he is the next speaker for the Liberal Party and I would encourage him to withhold his comments until that time.
The net public debt will begin to shrink as a proportion of the economy in 1993-94 for the first time since 1973-74.
Reducing the deficit is essential for a return to sustained economic growth and new jobs. It is an essential foundation for a return of confidence, at home and abroad, that will ensure a strong recovery. Most important, the measures in the budget will not compromise our deficit reduction goals.
Continued spending restraint will help bring about a major reduction in government borrowing. The government's financial requirements will be reduced to zero in 1995-96. The government will then begin to reduce its outstanding debt in the financial markets for the first time since 1969-70.
It is in this context of deficit reduction that we must consider Bill C-61.
Government Orders

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Who wrote that?

I did. I wrote it. In case you wanted to know, I wrote it. It's a good speech too.
Like borrowing bills in recent years, this bill contains three basic elements: financing authority to cover financial requirements for 1992-93; an amount to cover exchange fund account profits; and a contingency reserve. In total, the government is requesting authority to borrow $24.7 billion for the 1992-93 fiscal year.
It bears noting that the House committee has reviewed the provisions of the bill and has reported back with no amendments.
In addition, there is provision for an additional borrowing authority of $3.9 billion to provide for borrowings conducted in this fiscal year under section 47 of the Financial Administration Act. There are also a number of technical changes to tie the bill more closely to the fiscal year.
Before I finish my remarks, I would like to draw the attention of hon. members to the fact that the government has been operating under section 47 of the Financial Administration Act since January 28 of this year. Various factors contributed to this, particularly the increase in financial requirements as reported in the budget.
Let me remind members that until new borrowing authority is in place, only short-term debt instruments can be sold, and the government cannot maintain the desired balance of short and long term debt in its debt program. This balance is carefully designed to achieve the objectives of cost minimization and reduced exposure to increases in debt service changes. It is therefore important that Bill C-61 be considered in a timely manner.
The amount of borrowing authority requested in the bill is directly connected to the budget and the financial requirements stated therein. The information required to deal with the financial aspects of the bill is set out in the budget documents.
I therefore urge the House to proceed with this legislation as quickly as possible so that new borrowing authority will be in place at the beginning of the new

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
fiscal year and the government's regular borrowing program can proceed as the fiscal year begins.
Our record of spending restraint and deficit reduction offers sound testimony that this country's finances are being handled prudently and responsibly.
I urge all members to support this bill.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the unbelievable statement of the minister with which he closed his brief address was, of course, one that I will seek to refute in the time allotted to me today. It is obvious that he could not have said that with a straight face. I was amazed that a wide grin did not break out on his face as he uttered those statements. I was also amused to hear him suggest that this bill should get speedy passage because the government had run out of borrowing authority on January 28 and was having to borrow all of its money on the money markets on short-term notes.
Doesn't that make sense?

It does make sense. The trouble is that it just shows incompetent management. If the government had asked for the proper borrowing authority last year instead of underestimating its requirements, as it did, I say to the minister, he would have not been into this mess and would not be here today pressing us for speedy passage.
We were assured last year that the borrowing authority that was asked for was more than sufficient. The government had everything covered and everything planned. Now we see in fact that not only did it not have it properly planned, it misplanned it. It botched it as usual and of course now the Canadian taxpayers are paying the price of this bungled, incompetent government which cannot manage a lemonade stand let alone the administration of the Government of Canada.
The purpose of this bill, as everyone has stated, is to permit the government to borrow to cover the annual deficit that it is running up in this country. It said that the deficit this year is going to be lower than last. Time will tell. If so, it will be the first time in about four years that the government has managed to get it down. Every year it is trumpeted by Ministers of Finance how wonderfully this government is managing things, that it has managed to cut the debt, it is really working and deficit control is a big priority, but every year the deficit goes up. For the
last four years, the deficit has continually risen and 1991-92 was no exception.
In the new financial year, and we will see, the minister says it is going down to $27 billion. But the minister has been wrong before, almost consistently, and so time will tell whether he manages to get this one right. In any event, his deficit is unduly large and I will make some commentary on it later in my remarks.
I want to draw to the attention of the House what the results of the Conservative policies have been. I want to deal specifically with my own riding of Kingston and the Islands where the hardship that has been wrought by this government's disastrous combination of policies has been severe. It is estimated that in Kingston, 1 of every 25 people is collecting welfare benefits and this does not include those receiving family benefits or unemployment insurance.
In 1989 Kingston's welfare payments totalled $5.2 million. In 1990 the figure was $8.6 million. In 1991 it will be approximately $14 million by the end of the year. That is almost triple its level in 1989.
It is predicted this upward trend will continue with an estimated further 60 per cent growth in case-loads over the next year. This could bring welfare payments over the $26 million mark by the end of 1992, compared with only $5.2 million in 1989. The welfare case-load in the Kingston area is up 140 per cent in 1991 over the 1990 figures. The provincial average is even higher than that.
I am sure that the minister of state for homelessness will be interested in the fact that the welfare payments in Kingston are higher in 1991 than they have been at any time in the past decade by almost double. It is a disastrous situation brought about by a series of disastrous policies.
In building permits, total building permit activity in the Kingston area was down 14.7 per cent over the 1990 total. Kingston fared reasonably well in that respect. The industrial and commercial and residential building permits comprised 77 per cent of total building activity down from 90 per cent in 1990. Housing starts in the greater Kingston area fell from a total of 1,199 starts in 1990 to 644 starts in 1991, almost half.
That is the record the minister boasts about when he says this government-I hope I have not lost his words, they were so memorable-"was managing prudently and
March 23, 1992

well". I do not consider that set of figures to be prudence or competence in management.
There are more disturbing figures. The food banks in the Kingston area experienced significant growth in 1991 over 1990 figures, a growth of 15.6 per cent in the number of parcels delivered. It is clear that they are not always able to meet all the demands placed on them. That is the report from the Partners in Mission Food Bank operating in Kingston.
There are other disturbing trends in the economy that the government has failed to address. The Canadian Federation of Labour in a recent survey it conducted in the fall of 1991 found that 36 per cent of Ontario's small businesses are considering moving all or part of their operations out of the province.
The minister, I am sure, has some personal knowledge of businesses that have moved out of his riding. Later in my remarks I will be referring to some of the ones that have moved out of my riding of Kingston and the Islands.
They have moved out for two reasons. I will grant the minister that. It is not just the policies of the federal government; it is also the policies of the provincial government in Ontario that have caused heartache and disturbance to thousands of people and they are leaving the province like flies.
The hon. member for Oshawa is laughing. He, of course, used to be a supporter of that government. He can afford to laugh. He got out of the morass. He got off the sinking ship before it dragged the province down. He is still laughing. I am surprised he would take such a callous attitude toward his constituents.
This year bankruptcies are running 50 per cent ahead of last year, with retailers hardest hit followed by manufacturers, wholesalers, restaurants and construction companies. What we have in Canada today is a lot of bad news brought about by a government which is unable to deal with economic problems in a rational and meaningful way.
The world-wide recession is what is blamed by the government for the present mess. But we all know that the recession in Canada started before it started anywhere else and is worse in Canada than it is almost anywhere else. The reason that it is worse and the reason it started sooner is because of the policies of the government.
Government Orders
There were three major policies that have caused this difficulty for our country and I will go through each of them in turn. First, free trade; second, tax reform Tory style; and, third, high interest rates.
The free trade agreement, which the government negotiated and said was going to save Canada from everything, has been a complete disaster for this country. The minister laughs. He knows that is true. He knows how many jobs have been lost in his own riding. I know that there have been a significant number of jobs lost in my riding attributable directly to free trade. It is not just the recession; it is people moving out. That has made the recession worse in Canada. It has crippled Canadian industry in a way that has not happened in this century, at least not since the great depression.
The chief negotiator for Canada, Simon Reisman, who sold this country out, who gave it away to the Americans in the free trade negotiations, has consistently tried to hide his incompetence. Now he is apologizing for the deal in effect saying that perhaps the Americans are playing unfair, that they are not doing what they said they would do, they are not living up to their side of the bargain. Well, he did not get it in writing; he gave everything away. He had the wool pulled over his eyes by the Americans.
We said so during the campaign. What was his response? He called the Leader of the Opposition at the time a traitor. With respect, I think we know who the traitor was.
I think this free trade deal has cost Canadians jobs. It has cost jobs in my riding. It has cost jobs across the country but particularly in Ontario.
I have some quotations I would like to read about what has gone on. A major plant in Kingston that employed a little over 60 employees when it closed was K. D. Manufacturing. I will read part of the article that appeared in the Kingston The Whig-Standard last fall:
K.D. Manufacturing operated in Kingston for more than 70 years as the largest producer of wooden picture frames in Canada. Its 60-plus employees worked in the Montreal Street plant for an average of 20 years. At one time more than 100 workers were employed there.
But now the company is enjoying the advantages of free trade on the other side of the border.
The whole plant, which was family owned, closed down in Kingston and moved south of the border.

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
I quote here from the owner of the company, Howard Kelly. He said: "We have been pleased with the move because of our sales retention. We didn't lose much of our business". He added that about 90 per cent of his business was still in Canada. Free trade makes it easier to sell goods in both countries. Ninety per cent of your business is in Canada, and you move to the United States. That is the advantage of the free trade deal that the government talks about so enthusiastically. "Most important it now allows us to manufacture products more competitively with our North American competitors and gives us more exposure to the U.S. market", he said. "Free trade, cheaper non-union labour, a new market and a state loan were all factors but there are no simple explanations".
A state loan to help set up business, where was the government with its adjustment programs for Canadian workers to help this kind of business stay in Canada? There were not any.
I have another series of quotes. The Whig-Standard the same day published an article about whether or not free trade had created a level playing field:
Despite the free trade agreement, Kingston's economic development officer is concerned that Canadian companies are being pressured to open plants in the U.S.
Wejay Machine Products Co. Ltd., which designs and builds custom, automated material-handling and packaging machines for the aluminum, steel, paper and textiles industries, is one company Kingston Township expanding its presence in the U.S. market.
I am sure it meant from Kingston Township but it does not say that in the article. So here was a company operating in Canada that felt it could not get business in the United States unless it opened a branch plant in that country and started producing its products there.
I quote from Mr. David Cash, Kingston's very competent economic development officer. He said:
But it seems to me that the spirit of the free trade agreement is such that a U.S. company shouldn't discriminate against a company located in Canada.
We were told that was exactly what free trade was going to do. That is what Simon was running around the country saying. That is what the Prime Minister was running around the country saying. That is what the Minister of Finance at the time was running around the country saying. Who was telling the truth? We did not get that kind of deal.
Then Mr. Cash said, and I quote again from the
article:
Mr. Cash is still concerned that the free trade agreement is not working out the way it was supposed to do. "The whole idea of free trade was, and still is, that you can serve your American market from Canada without duties, so I get concerned whenever U.S. companies are pressuring their suppliers in Canada to move or expand their operations into the States, but I don't know what I can do about it.
It seems to me to be a fairly new and emerging concern."
It is a concern, but one that this government ignores completely. There is absolutely nothing that the government is doing to assist in this problem.
We had the Prime Minister rattling his sabres the other day saying that maybe there was some problem and the United States was being unfair in free trade. Of course, he is a great friend of the President. We have all heard what good terms he and the President are on. He and the former President used to sing duets together, but it is not doing any good now. Canadian industry is still suffering as a result of the free trade deal and this government's policy in supporting it.
I want to quote from the Prime Minister again. I quote from a more recent edition of The Whig-Standard, March 17. There was an excellent article written by Ian Austen of Southam News which was printed in the paper. It quotes the Prime Minister. Listen to this; this is unbelievable. He says:
Our highest priority is to have an agreement that ends the threat to Canadian industry from U.S. protectionists who harass and restrict our exports through the use of trade remedy laws.
That is what the Prime Minister is quoted as having said in the House of Commons in March 1987.
We all know that that objective was not achieved in the free trade negotiations. The government failed Canadians in getting what it said was a prime objective. "It was the highest priority", the Prime Minister said. Of course, we have heard him say things like that before and we all know that he is talking through his hat.
The article goes on to say about the free trade deal that:
The lingering problems are two-fold: The trade agreement has neither changed the way the Americans operate nor made solving disputes any faster.
It states quite correctly:

As for the Honda case, the free trade agreement doesn't even offer the hope of a binding settlement.
The two governments are in the early stages of setting up a bi-national panel to review the dispute. But in this and all customs cases, neither government will be bound by its findings.
The article refers to Mr. Ritchie, the deputy negotiator who helped poor old Simon try to sell the country out, and says:
Mr. Ritchie now acknowledges it is a major flaw in the deal he helped create.
Of course this was supposed to create all these jobs and it did not. But the government does not seem concerned about unemployment. It has done nothing in the budget to assist the unemployed. The article goes on to say:
As well, during the recession 10 years ago, only 22 per cent of those left unemployed in Ontario lost their jobs because of permanent factory closings. Today the figure is 65 per cent.
That was the 1981-82 recession that we hear so much about from this government. Twenty-two per cent of those left unemployed in Ontario lost their jobs because of permanent factory closings. Today the figure is 65 per cent. It is 65 per cent who are out of work because of permanent factory closings.
I suggest to the minister-and he knows this probably better than I but does not want to admit it-the reason that all those factories have closed is because of the free trade deal. It has been a disaster, and it is a cornerstone of Tory policy under this government.
The second cornerstone is tax reform, Tory-style. By that I refer of course to the goods and services tax. We have had a massive tax shift in Canada since this government took office in 1984, and it is a tax shift that I suggest to you is the reason Canadians all across Canada are complaining that taxes are too high. The government does not heed these complaints. It has lowered them very slightly in this budget, but the reduction is so minuscule that it is difficult to measure in most Canadian pocketbooks.
Canadians know they are paying a lot more in taxes, and they are right. What has happened is that we have had a change from the world of corporate tax as a means
Government Orders
of raising revenue to the field of personal tax. The Tories are hitting the people who are least able to pay. That is what is going on, and I have some figures to support that.
First of all, in a recent Maclean's article, I think it was just a week or two ago, there was a graph showing budgetary revenues as a percentage of total federal spending. Where does the money come from?
In 1984, 41 per cent of the revenue came from personal income tax. Forty-one per cent of federal spending was raised by means of personal income tax. Today, it is 47.7 per cent, a very significant increase.
Corporate income taxes in 1984 accounted for 13.2 per cent of the revenues used for government spending. Today, it is 7.2 per cent, a very significant reduction. What the government has done is it has taken the taxes off the corporations and has transferred the tax to the individuals. That is exactly what it has done.
The minister shakes his head. He knows this is accurate. There is nothing inaccurate about this. If he pulls out the government's own taxation figures from the raw figures he will see that there has been a reduction in corporate taxes as a percentage. It is not difficult to see that and this graph, I suggest, has shown this. It shows that that is the case and it is an accurate graph.
Sales and excise tax revenues have actually decreased over the period. The graph is based on an estimate of the GST revenues for 1992-93. One suspects that if the GST were applied in a normal economic year, not one where there is a recession, the revenues would be much higher. But time will tell, time will tell.
Oh, we are up to 40 now.
Yes, but as a percentage of the total grab I think the member knows the GST would be higher.
What about corporate income taxes?
So would corporate income taxes, so would personal income tax, but as a percentage of the total I am suggesting to the member that the GST would in fact be more.

Liberal economics.

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
The hon. member says: "Liberal economics". I can tell him that Canadians would much prefer Liberal economics at this stage, and all the polls indicate it.
Oh, oh.

If the hon. member is so sure that is not true, I urge him to advise the Prime Minister to call an election and we will find out.
The Conservatives would like Canadians to believe that this latest budget offers Canadians a significant tax break when in fact we all know it does not. Thming to the reduction in the personal income surtax, that tax was originally brought in by this government in 1986 and was subsequently increased on two occasions. It was one of the 40 changes in personal income tax the government has brought in to soak Canadian taxpayers.
We are up to 40 now.

Forty changes to personal income tax which have resulted in increases for Canadians. The change in this tax offers virtually no relief. The reduction in the surtax actually benefits high income earners more than low income earners. For a family of four-
Oh, oh.

I see the minister is laughing. He should listen to these figures because maybe it would make him sing a different tune in cabinet meetings where they discuss these matters.
For a family of four with a combined income of $15,000, this tax cut will result in a savings of $2 for 1992. If the same family had an income of $75,000, it would save $74 in 1992.
How much did the ones with $15,000 pay?
The hon. member probably knows that answer better than I do. After all, he is a minister of the Crown who has at his fingertips all the figures he should need for answering those kinds of questions.
Very little, if any.

The goods and services tax, as well as being the most unpopular tax in Canadian history, has contributed to inflation in this country. The figures are all out on that. Over one per cent of last year's inflation was attributed directly to the goods and services tax and it has cost Canadians dearly. It has driven Canadians
across the border in a cross-border shopping revolt, which has driven more Canadians out of business, exacerbating the recession created by the high interest rate policy of the government.
I turn to that as the third tenet of Tory economic mismanagement in Canada. They have pursued a policy of high interest rates and it has been a disaster. It was the high interest rate policy that initially caused the recession in the first place. It was one of the major contributing causes to the recession. It is the thing that slowed Canada down and brought Canadian industry to its knees at a time when the rest of the world was not yet experiencing this kind of slow-down. The fact that high interest rates have continued throughout the time that we have lingered in this recession has only served to make matters worse.
Canadians may be easily deceived into thinking that because interest rates have dropped they are somehow low. But in fact if we accept the government's figures that the year-over-year inflation rate is 1.6 per cent in January and 1.7 per cent in February, and if the bank rate is at 7 per cent or 7.5 per cent or 7.75 per cent, then clearly the real interest rate being paid by Canadians is still over 5 per cent, and that is unacceptable. It is too high. It is costing Canadians much more than any other group in the industrialized world is paying in terms of real interest costs.
That high interest cost is a disaster for Canadian business. It means that anybody seeking to carry on or operate a business in Canada and borrow money in the process, pays more than his or her American counterpart. It means that anybody seeking to borrow money for any purpose is going to pay higher rates than his or her American counterpart. The high interest rate keeps the dollar high so that Canadian exports are more expensive than they would otherwise be. If the dollar were allowed to drop to a more reasonable level, closer to where it should be, then Canadian exports would flourish. There would be generation of new jobs in Canada and prosperity could be restored. But the government persists in this high interest rate policy led by the Governor of the Bank of Canada.
The fact that the governor is intent on wrestling inflation to the ground is his supposed justification for this ridiculous policy. Frankly we have always managed with some inflation throughout this century. At times it has been unacceptably high, but we have had inflation
March 23, 1992

for a long time. Not since the 1930s have we had deflation. The governor of the bank backed by the Minister of Finance and the Minister of State for Finance have been supporting this high interest policy which I suggest is unacceptable. The result of it is high unemployment, lost business opportunities, the loss of businesses to the United States, and a difficult market for Canada's export commodities.
I would like to quote from an article that appeared in The Globe and Mail on December 5 by Mario Dalla-Vicenza from Regina. He is senior vice-president and chief financial officer of Ipsco. Here is what he had to say about the government's disastrous high interest rate policy:
Stable prices may be a legitimate and necessary goal of the Bank of Canada, but the short-sighted and overzealous tactics it is using to achieve this goal are cause for concern. In fact, these tactics are bringing the economy of Canada to its knees.
That is what he said. The minister and the other members of his government clearly ignored this kind of advice. He went on:
The bank's policy of high interest rates, which brings with it an artificially high value of the Canadian dollar, has crucified the mining, forestry, farming and goods producing sectors of the Canadian economy.
That is the opinion of a respected businessman in western Canada, and we know the government loves to listen to businessmen. The Tories always claim they are running the Government of Canada like a business, but if anybody else ran a business the way they run the Government of Canada they would be out of business.
Don McGillivray, a respected financial journalist, wrote a column on February 25 in The Ottawa Citizen in which he said:
There never has been political support in Canada for an attempt to wrestle inflation to the ground, no matter what unemployment resulted. There is less support for such a policy now near the end of the second year of a painful recession for which the Bank of Canada must bear part of the blame.
That doesn't alter the fact that the governor believes himself to be correct. He told the Commons committee that there is no basis for believing that monetary policy can focus on a number of different targets at the same time.
He seems to live in a more neat and tidy world than the rest of us.
Government Orders
I think everybody in the House would agree with that statement. He continued:
It's a world where action to achieve one simple goal is unrelentingly pursued, where action can deal with what ails the economy.
The governor has overreached himself and suffered a rebuke. His policies did not command much confidence on the part of Canadians before. They command less support now.
Canadians have seen how a single minded pursuit of zero inflation hurts things they care deeply about. They want the central bank to worry too.
"They want the government to worry too", he might have added to the article. The government ignores this problem and has allowed the governor to continue on this ridiculous course that has cost Canadians and has cost Canadians dearly.
It is part of a three-pronged effort on the part of the government to destroy the Canadian economy, it would appear. It does not listen to anybody who has any criticisms or sensible suggestions for improving the situation. I may say that includes the suggestions coming from me in this speech. However the minister may be paying closer attention than he lets on.
The minister brought in a budget that he claimed was a good news budget. The minister sounded optimistic and rosy: everything was going to be fine by 1993 and in 1992 we would get by and with the tax breaks he was offering Canadians everybody would feel good.
Let us just see how the budget was received by Canadians. I suggest Canadians know this budget was not what the government trumped it up to be. It was not all the good news that the government said it was.
I would like to quote first from the Canadian Chamber of Commerce. One would think this group, being a group of businessmen, would be one the government would listen to. After all, the government says it is running the Government of Canada like a business. These people are businessmen. I presume they know what they are doing. They certainly know a lot more of what they are doing than the government does.
Let us look at what the Chamber said:
The chamber, Canada's largest business group, expressed disappointment that the government had once again strayed from its commitment to serious deficit reduction, delaying harsh action for at least another year.

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
We heard the minister in his speech say how they had cut back and how we were going to have the deficit reduced. Well time will tell. It has gone up for four years, as I said, but it may go down this year.
The news release quotes Tim Reid, president of the chamber, in case the minister did not know. It continued:
First, he noted that the government's program expenditures are forecast to rise by 4.7 per cent in fiscal 1992-93, well in excess of the 2.7 per cent inflation rate. "That doesn't tell us there's a very firm commitment to containing spending in areas where it counts", said Reid.
A good quote, I thought, and a valid criticism. If the government says it is doing one thing and doing another, there is something wrong. It goes on:
Secondly, the 1992-93 deficit (now forecast at $27.5 billion) is "significantly higher than had been predicted in earlier budgets"-
It certainly is. My recollection of the 1985 budget was that by this year the deficit would be down to something like $10 billion. Perhaps the hon. member for Oshawa can remember the figures better. I think $8 billion or $10 billion was what it was supposed to be. Now it is at $27 billion. Last year the government told us that it was going to be $24 billion, but I do not want to go through all those figures. I know the minister finds them very tedious.
It continued:
-is significantly higher than had been predicted in earlier budgets"-"and far too high when you consider that it will be added to an accumulated debt load that already stands at $420 billion, and is the most severe in the industrial world with the exception of Italy."
Of course the minister and his colleagues like to blame the previous Liberal government for the deficit. They do not know what else to do. After all they have doubled it, but they all say: "Of course it is not our fault. It is all somebody else's fault". Everything is somebody else's fault.
Going back to the news release, it continued:
Thirdly, there is the debt to GDP ratio, the relationship between the debt and our ability to pay it. Noted Reid, "In the last budget, they promised us that it would fall next year-for the first time in this government's mandate-to under 60 per cent. Now they admit it will rise to over 62 per cent, and that's also one of the worst in the industrialized world".
I have more quotes on that, because for years the government has been planning to get some control on this debt to GDP ratio. One of the things it boasts about is how the debt to GDP ratio is something that it can bring under control. It always puts in figures about how the annual deficit is shrinking as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product. Of course it is, when we consider that the Gross Domestic Product is usually growing and the government has managed to keep the deficit size a fairly level one. It has gone up, but very slowly.
Let us hear what the government said in its economic and fiscal statement in November 1984. It said:
A continuously rising ratio of debt to income threatens growth in three ways. It puts upward pressure on interest rates by raising expectations of future inflation and by competing for private savings. It limits the government's ability to meet priority economic and social needs. And it symbolizes a state of economic mismanagement that undermines confidence and threatens the job creating private investment that Canada needs.
Fiscal policy must ease the burden on monetary policy and contribute directly to increased confidence and to lower interest rates.
That is what they said in 1984. One does wish they had heeded their own advice. They have maintained a large deficit, have continually put upward pressure on interest rates, have raised expectations of future inflation and have competed with private savings. They have ignored their own policy statement for seven or eight years.
In 1989 the minister said:
The actions taken in this budget are designed first to stabilize, and then to lower the debt to GDP ratio. It stabilizes at just over 56 per cent of GDP in 1990-91.
Well, it did not. It is going to 62 per cent in 1992-93. But the government ignores that: it is just a change and is not a case of incompetent management. It would not admit to that. Everybody in Canada, I would suggest, knows it is.
In the fiscal plan in 1988, the government said:
By 1991-92 the debt to GDP ratio declines.
It does not. In the February 1991 budget the government said:
The growth in public debt as a proportion of GDP is halted in 1991-92, the first time its upward trend has been arrested since 1974-75.
March 23, 1992

Of course that was wrong. It was not. Thereafter, it declines steadily throughout the fiscal framework period.
In other words, the government has been consistently wrong in its dealings with the public debt problems and with deficit problems. It has not been able to get a grip on the subject, despite the rhetoric and statements that it was bringing the debt, the GDP ratio, under control and was bringing it under control right away.
I see the hon. member for Winnipeg South has floated in. I hope that she is enjoying my comments because she is a person who has some influence on the government and could perhaps go to the cabinet meeting some day and urge these ministers to do something to clean up the mess they have created after seven years of mismanagement.
In case anybody thinks that by quoting only the chamber I am giving a distorted view of Canadians' ideas about this budget, I want to quote from a Gallup poll.
[Translation}
Fewer than one out of four Canadians (23 per cent) who were familiar with the latest federal Budget felt that it would strengthen Canada's economy. Most respondents (59 per cent) felt that the measures announced in the February 25 Budget by the Minister of Finance, Don Mazankowski, would do nothing for the economy, while 18 per cent had no opinion.
This is a poll that was published in today's La Presse. [English]
Only 23 per cent of Canadians think that the budget is going to do something to help the economy. Everybody else, the vast majority of Canadians, thinks it will do absolutely nothing.
The hon. minister asks if the 1982 results are in it. I do not see the 1982 results in it.
I have another quotation from Don McGillivray. The minister groans. Obviously he does not agree with what Mr. McGillivray writes, but most Canadians realize that Mr. McGillivray is a fair, honest and objective commentator on the government's economic performance. In a recent article he said: "We have lost two years of normal growth in the economy. We have lost the output of about two million workers. We have told this army of Canadians that their country has no use for them. They will bear the scars of this recession for the rest of their lives.
Government Orders
If that is not a good reason to kick up a bit of a fuss about the economy, what is?"
That is exactly what we have been trying to do; to get the government to do something to alleviate the unemployment that it has created by these three disastrous policy initiatives.
I am tempted to quote from another very capable source, the hon. member for Ottawa South, my learned and very competent colleague. He made a speech in this House on second reading of this bill on February 28. It was an excellent speech. I would have thought that after hearing a speech as the hon. member for Ottawa South made, the government would have packed its bags and left office right away. It was such a devastating condemnation of its policies that you would think the government would get out. It was obvious that there was something seriously wrong with the Government of Canada.
He said: "This is the tired budget of a tired government, perplexed by the problems that confront it, though many are of its own making; showing no vision, no imagination, not even comprehension of the difficulties Canada must tackle before the end of the century".
That is a fair comment on the budget and one that reflects the views of hundreds of thousands of Canadians across this country. They are appalled at the government's callous attitude.
Finally, I would like to quote from another extremely competent writer on these matters, Bruce Little, an economics reporter for The Globe and Mail. He has had a distinguished career in writing for financial publications in Canada. I believe he was managing editor for The Globe and Mail at one time.
In a recent article he said: "This recession is different. Canada's last downturn was deep, but when it was over, the economy rebounded smartly and cleanly into what turned out to be the long expansion of the 1980s.
This downturn has been shallower but far messier. Almost two full years after the recession began, the economy is still scuttling crab-like across the landscape, unable to set a clear course".

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
He went on to say: "Corporate profits have been scoured like never before. Last time, pre-tax profits fell 40 per cent in the first year of the recession. In less than two years, they bounced back to pre-recession levels. In this recession, they followed the same track for five quarters, then parted company. In the final three months of 1991, they were 44 per cent below levels reached two years ago".
In other words, corporate profits just bottomed out. Going into the last recession, profits were 11.8 per cent of GDP and went as low as 7 per cent before recovering. This time, profits were only 7.5 per cent of GDP on the way in and have since fallen to 4.1 per cent, the lowest level since the great depression of the 1930s.
It is that kind of grim economic picture painted by economic writers across Canada that one might have thought would be reflected in the budget. One would think that the Minister of Finance would have said that the government has to do something to try to ease this crisis. Instead, the government has done nothing.
The Liberal Party has put forward a series of proposals to the government to suggest that it do something to get the economy rolling again. Two of the proposals have been adopted: the change in the down payment requirements for new housing, and the allowance for the RRSP moneys to be used to finance the purchase of a house. Those are both suggestions put forward by the Leader of the Opposition in the course of a recent pre-budget speech urging the government to take these steps. The government has seen fit to do both.
The other two major parts of the platform have been ignored, namely the assistance for municipalities and assistance for food banks.

Mr. Speaker, I am interested in what has transpired here this morning and I want to congratulate the minister. Essentially the minister had nothing to say this morning and he managed to do that in four pages. We should all be immensely grateful that he at least was concise.
To the member for Kingston and the Islands, we should all thank his press clipping service. The clippings expanded substantially on the quality of the speech and they certainly added to the quantity of his speech. The problem is that there is a gem of truth there, but at this time of year the seeds are covered in a certain layer of
horse manure, and it will take at lot of heat and light before they germinate. The hope will be that sometime later this year we will actually have a spring in Ottawa and there will be some germination and some growth.
My problem is that the member presents life in a caricature form. He pretends that by reading extensively from newspapers across the country, one can get some sense of the conditions under which most Canadians labour at the moment. I do not believe you can. I believe that those people who write newspaper columns are doing the best they can to present accurately their opinions, the facts as they see them, the effect of the depression on the Canadian economy at the moment. It is very difficult for them, as it is for us in this Chamber. For most Canadians, there will be no trip to Taiwan. There will be no tour of Europe. There will be no break. There will be no respite from the masses. There will be no free lunch. There will be no chance to be inside and warm this winter. For many of our Canadian people, this is going to be the culmination of a very difficult period and it is not getting any better.
That cry of frustration is there and very strong. Some have used the episode of food banks and the fact that they are being used more extensively now, even more perhaps than during the Great Depression in Canada. They are being used by different people. The poor are not quite so easily identified anymore. It is easy to identify those who are homeless. It is not so easy to identify the reasons why people who used to think of themselves as good productive taxpayers in Canada, part of the mainstream fabric of our society, do not have a job anymore.
It is very difficult to listen to the frustration of those people who have done all of the things that their society said they have to do to get a good job and the job is not there any more.
It is difficult to explain to them that when their factory closes these days, it is most likely not to be a lay-off or a downturn or a change in our economy. It is difficult to explain to them why the whole plant has left Canada.
Some will attribute this as being the fault of the global market, the fault of any particular government. It really does not matter to most Canadians who is at fault here. They do not care whether it is this government or that government or somebody in Geneva or somebody in
March 23, 1992

Taiwan. What they care about is their own human condition; that in their own self-interest, having done what society said they ought to do, they do not even have the opportunity to seek gainful employment any more. That is a tragedy that is not carried very often in our public media, not carried very often in our popular press.
It is one of those things worthy of a story once a year, or if someone gets really serious about it, a series of seven or eight stories on how the poor are surviving the depression. I watch the media every day. Members have this fault. We are obsessed by what the media has to say. Every once in a while some television station in some major city will hear of a lay-off, a shut-down. It will rush out there and for about one or two minutes, or if it gets real excited, four or five minutes, it will run a story about people's lives, about the impact of the shutting down of that plant on the economy of Cornwall, Kingston, Oshawa or any other community.
I have yet to see it go back the second day when the cameras are not around and ask people what it is like that day, the third day, the fourth day, and after five and six months. That is the difference in perspective. The Canadian people do not have the luxury of watching their lives fall apart for 30 seconds at a time. For them, it lasts for a much longer period and the ramifications are much worse.
Part of what I would object to in this budget, as I would with the province of Ontario, any of the other provinces or any other budget that I have ever seen, is that the version of restraint that is sometimes preached in this Chamber is a lot different than the one that is reality back home. It is fine for ministers of the Crown to say they spent to much money, so they are going to have to chop this and chop that. It is fine for this government in its latest budget proposal to say it cannot do the things it wants to do, so it will not have a child care program. For a government, that is an economic decision on how to put together a budget, an expression of political priorities. Once the decision is reached, it is over with.
The ministers of the Crown simply have to explain for two or three days, if the reporters are insistent, why it is that children are in poverty in this great wealth called Canada. The ministers of the Crown at best will have to spend a few hours of their time explaining to interest groups and to members of the House of Commons why
Government Orders
children cannot have child care, why children will have to live the rest of their lives without it.
To a minister who has to defend this government policy, this is awkward, this is painful, but only for a short period of time. While they do that and while they explain that and while they rationalize all of that, they are mindful, as we all would be, that this will go away. For the child, for the mother, for the parent and for the nation, this will not go away.
I read with interest that the government is considering a few other changes. Excuse me for being cynical, but I heard a minister of the Crown say that medicare is a sacred trust. Some days I wish I had just started in politics. I wish that I did not know any better. I wish that when some minister of the Crown said something was a sacred trust the little alarms did not go off in my head. I have heard that far too many times.
Whenever someone says something is a sacred trust, it is a real good gamble that it is going, that it is in trouble, that somebody somewhere is thinking about really cutting this one.
As someone who has been involved in political life in Canada, it bothers me somewhat that at the end of 20 years, when a minister of the Crown says something is a sacred trust, I get worried. I become concerned about what is really on the agenda. What is going on here? What do they really mean? I have been through it long enough to know that when they start using that kind of language up front, something really dastardly is happening down near the other end. It is similar to the middle of a political campaign when people are stupid enough-I use those words advisedly-to accept anybody from any political stripe when they say: "We are going to institute a national child care policy. We are going to provide child care to people all over Canada". People should say: "Wait a minute. Who are you? Have you every done that before in your lives? Is that really what you want to do? Is that your priority? Did you do the same thing with some other promise that you made and not questioned or not challenged that".
I think the faults in politics are many. Some are inside this Chamber. More of them are outside this Chamber. There are people who say: "I liked the look of his jaw. I liked their campaign jingle. I liked the way their literature is designed. They have a snappy ad that says I should

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
vote this way or that way". The Canadian people have to learn how to make their political judgments in a much tougher way.
There are those who relish the notion that this government is bottoming out in the polls, as they say. It has been at the bottom before. That does not bother it at all. The election is not on at the moment.
I noticed that the minister, in his introductory remarks, said that by 1996 the need to borrow money is going to be reduced to zero. If the Canadian people get a chance to intervene somewhere between now and 1996, it will be reduced to zero a lot earlier than that. I hope that the Canadian people never make this kind of a mistake again.
To be as blunt as I can, this is a political government that has made its priorities clear. It has established who it represents, where its political priorities are, and it did it again with this budget. The new catch phrase is "targeting". The Minister of Finance says he wants to target the moneys a little better. That is exactly what the government did. Let me give an example.
In the field of housing, several people suggested that first time homeowners are having some trouble. Maybe if they had RRSPs you could let them use that money to buy their first home. A small perversion of that scheme is to broaden it just a little bit and say that anybody who has RRSPs can use their money to buy any house. It does not have to be their first house. It does not have to be modest. The government knows that people who have money put away in these kinds of savings plans are also likely to have a house. Therefore, when you read the fine print in the proposals the government made in its budget, you begin to get some understanding that it does not care a hoot whether it is a first time homeowner or not. It knows that it most likely will not be.
If they have money in that kind of a savings plan, they probably are not looking at buying their first house. The early trends in the real estate industry are that it is not first time homeowners, it is second and third time homeowners, and they are buying larger houses and there is a heck of a good tax break for them to do that. Would we not all be stupid if we thought the Canadian people would not read the fine print before they made that kind of an investment? That is exactly what they are doing.
Who is it helping? It is helping the upper and middle-income groups to get into the larger houses. There is nothing wrong with that at all, but to pretend somehow that it is other than a real estate gimmick would be quite wrong. As one who said it was an idea worth considering, I am a little unhappy on how that got targeted at the end of the process to a group that was not asking for more help and away from a group that really needed some help. It bothers me somewhat that they did that.
Here is one of the things I object to in politics these days. The government said, prior to the throne speech, that it was going to allow people to have 5 per cent down payments. That will stimulate sales in real estate somewhat and there is nothing wrong with that at all. It should also have said: "Consumer alert. There are people who should not be getting into 95 per cent mortgages. Take a good look at this. Here is an option you did not have before that you do have now". In the hot real estate markets, real estate companies and those who build homes were already doing some of these things.
In a place called Cookstown, Ontario, just north of Toronto, as an example, let me show the end effects of this. Once the government had established that the 5 per cent limit was right, then it had to turn it over to its bureaucracy at CMHC, very find, hard working, diligent, honest and intelligent civil servants.
Somebody had to decide that there would be regulations. You cannot have laws any more without regulations, and they have to be applied in different ways.
When you go to Cookstown, Ontario, and if you stand on the four comers, you will be standing on the division point between three different areas. On one comer the upper limit for the houses that can have a 5 per cent down payment is $125,000. That was the original idea. Across the street it is $175,000. On the other comer it is $250,000.
That is the same comer. There are three houses and three different parts to that little intersection. People in Canada look at that and say: "What is going on down there? Do these people not know this is all in one small town in central Ontario?" They do, but we see the configuration of the mindset that sets in here so that a program which perhaps makes good sense, when it is announced, when it is translated on the ground, does not make quite such imminent good sense.
March 23, 1992

The Canadian people are beginning to understand a little bit better. This is a government that, in its budget this year, did not just target the way that it will apply benefits to people, but targeted the way there would be income tax reduction for those whom it thinks are worthwhile in our society, those in upper income groups.
It was interesting that when it looked at the area of Canadian manufacturers, the government thought that offshore manufacturers, offshore investment, ought to get a little better break than Canadians. That is strange for this government, purporting to be a national Canadian government.
I have been interested in following all the arguments around the free trade agreement and the expansion of that agreement into Mexico. I have watched some who have been fierce advocates of free trade with the United States now saying: "Wait a minute. That is foul. The Americans are not playing fair. This is doing bad things to the Honda plant in Alliston. This is doing bad things to the softwood lumber industry in Canada".
Here is what I do not understand. If the government of the day is such a great manager, if it understands industry and manufacturing so well, when did the Americans ever work not in their own best self-interest? I do not remember a time in history when they ever refused to do that, when they ever said otherwise.
An American entrepreneur is not necessarily in business to do good things all around the world. There are lots of Americans who do that, but those who are entrepreneurial in scope, who are in the business manufacturing sector, never pretended that the reason they run a manufacturing plant somewhere in the United States is to benefit Canada. They never pretended that for a moment.
People say that they are interpreting regulations the wrong way. Why would they not? It is in their best interests to do that. That is what they have always done. That is what they are continuing to do.
I saw a very interesting analysis of free trade with Canada and the United States and extending that into Mexico. It essentially said that the purpose of the
Government Orders
exercise was simply to provide American manufacturers with unfettered access into Canada and Mexico. That is what the free trade agreement with Canada did, and that is what the one with Mexico purports to do.
If you look at it from that perspective, that is a pretty good deal for an American manufacturer; take away all the restrictions that would come north into Canada, take away all the restrictions that might apply south into Mexico, make sure that you can use all the raw material, all the resources and pit one part of the North American continent against another and then sell madly to both markets.
It is oversimplification. In many ways that is what I see happening with the current free trade agreement with the United States. I see a simple extension of that into Mexico. From an American perspective, it makes eminent, good sense. Americans ought to be enthusiastic about that kind of a trade deal.
Canadians would be stupid to accept that. More and more Canadians are beginning now to say: "Wait a minute. The last time around, when you talked about free trade with the United States, we accepted that the Americans, by and large, are our friends, that we constantly work back and forth between Canada and the United States. Many of our industries here in Canada are branch plants of American industries. Okay, maybe we will try this thing and see whether it works out".
For the part of Canada that I come from in southern Ontario, the manufacturing heartland for Canada, the results have been disastrous.
To go back to that targeting theme that I was talking about a little bit earlier, it is not for everybody.
There are some entrepreneurs who have done quite nicely under the free trade agreement with the United States. The people who have paid the price are the people who generate the wealth, the workers in those plants. They are not there any more. People have been exercising their options to move their plants into the southern United States. It is not quite as rosy as it first

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
looked. It is not quite as good as you might have thought. The benefits are not exactly there. Once you are in place and manufacturing in the States, it is not quite as good as it looks in the brochure but it is kind of late in the day to talk about coming back into Canada. Therein lies the tragedy for this budgetary process.
Some of them are coming back.

The minister interjects that some of them are coming back, but they will have trouble getting through the borders with all the cross-border shopping. We will wait and see. I am a fair person. I am quite prepared to take a look at the analysis of a free trade agreement and see what the good side is and what the bad side is. Where I come from and for the area I represent, times are tough and we are getting hammered by a free trade agreement that is not stupid from an American perspective. It is a very good agreement from that perspective. It is only stupid from our side of the bargaining table.
I come from Oshawa, a town that has had difficult times this winter. Some people will look at the manufacturing sector, particularly automobiles, and say we kind of weathered the storm there a little bit in Oshawa. We have not, not by a long shot, and we know that. We are being pressured, as a lot of communities are in Canada, by General Motors to take a look at how we operate and what our trade union agreements are and what the community can do and just exactly what can happen that would make General Motors continue to function in our community.
We are looking at all of those things. A lot of these things are not very pleasant for us. A lot of them involve taking apart some of the things on which our successful economic union in Oshawa has been built on over the years: a trade union that can freely bargain for its membership; a company that can produce a quality product and that has access to a market in the United States. These are not simple things that you kind of pull apart.
We are working each and every day to see whether we can come to an agreement with General Motors that will make the Oshawa plants competitive in exactly the same way as the American plants are. We understand that is important, but that is not going to do us much good if we lose our jobs in the process.
In conclusion, I want to say that this is a government that has made its intentions clear. Surely there can be nobody left in Canada who doubts what this government
wants to do. It is the obligation of members on this side and the Canadian people to tell it what we think of it.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. member made reference to promises that were made, glossy brochures, all of these wild and wonderful things that happened during election campaigns, and how the people of Canada should not believe these things. Is he in essence saying that the people of Ontario should not have believed what the NDP promised in Ontario during the last election in its beautiful brochures? Mind you, he may be right, because the NDP in Ontario certainly has not followed through on many of its promises, if any at all.

Mr. Speaker, I watched a motion picture on the weekend called Blaze. It is a motion picture about a gentleman by the name of Earl K. Long, Governor of Louisiana at one time. One of the characters was told by her mother, before she went to New Orleans, that she should never trust a person who says "trust me." One of the first questions she put to Earl K. Long, Governor of the great State of Louisiana, was: "Can I trust you, Governor?" His response was: "Hell, no". It struck me that was a pretty good credo for modem politics. Most politicians, if they were honest, would say: "Wait a minute, this is not about you trusting me, this is about you analysing what I am all about. This is about you analysing my track record. You should understand that I may have all the good intentions in the world today, but if there is no money in the kitty tomorrow I am not going to be able to do the things I want to do".
It is not about reading brochures. It should not be about simply listening to commercials. It should not be about who has the best cosmetician to give them the best look for television. It should not be about who has the best press clipping service. It should be a careful, rational analysis about who works in my best interest, and I mean that in a very warm and personal way.
I suggest that those who would say otherwise have come to learn the grim lesson that my friends in the province of Ontario have had to leam since they took over from my good friends the Liberals. When we went through that election campaign, we began it with my good friend Bob Nixon, a very nice man, Treasurer of Ontario, a longstanding member of the Ontario legislature. Bob said: "Gee, things are great in Ontario. We have got like a $28 million surplus". Imagine that, in six short weeks it dropped to about a $200 million deficit. Was Bob Nixon misleading the people of Ontario? No,
March 23, 1992

he was not. I know the man. Bob Nixon was giving the people of Ontario the best information he had. He was wrong, very wrong, and we all regret that, but he did not mean to mislead anybody. He told them the information he had at that given moment in time, but circumstances change.
All of us had better get used to the idea that we are living in a very volatile society. I remind those Liberals who are gloating just a touch over here. When you get up to 54 per cent, right where David Peterson was at the beginning of that provincial election campaign and you are fighting like mad to cause the folks on this side of the aisle to start up a general election, before you start that chant in this Chamber, why do you not read a little bit about what happened to David Peterson, one of the most popular premiers that Ontario ever had, sitting at 54 per cent at the beginning of the election, and see what happened to him at the end of the process. That is the lesson all of us have to learn.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was quite amused to hear the hon. member at the outset of his remarks say that he wanted us to set aside in effect-he did not use these words-partisan considerations in looking at our assessment of policies and try to look at it from the point of view of what the average Canadian wants or expects from his government. It is of course a perfectly good objective.
I guess what I was trying to say in my speech, and that I know he tried to in his in a different way, was: " If this is what the average Canadian wants, where are you best going to get it". Really in an election campaign, which he talked about last, we come down to a choice. The electorate gets a choice between the group of men and women that the electorate thinks are best able to provide the kind of Canada that the electorate wants, that they are able to provide the kind of policies, the programs, the jobs, the opportunities that the Canadian voter at least wants when he or she makes his or her choice at the polls.
What I think he was trying to say in a different way was support the policies that the New Democratic Party is putting forward as a reasonable alternative to the policies that the Government of Canada is now doing. What he was trying to do was pretend that this was a non-partisan approach to government decision making or elector-
Govemment Orders
al decision making and of course, we all know that it is not.
I was a little more open in my comments. It was not any of this cloak and dagger stuff that perhaps he has been using a little facetiously here today in that I made it very clear that the choice of this government was a bad choice for Canada and Canadians across the country regret having chosen this group to be the government.
I wonder if he could tell us if he agrees that perhaps Ontario electors have ended up with a bad choice on two rounds now, both by choosing this government here, which has introduced policies that are inimical to the interests of Ontario, and in the choice of the New Democratic Party government which has adopted policies in the province and has scared investors in the province in a way that is inimical to the best interests of Ontarians.

Mr. Speaker, let me try to correct my friend on a couple of counts here. I am never non-partisan. I am probably the most fiercely partisan person you have ever met in your life. I have only belonged to one political party all my life. Warts and all, I am with them until the end.
I am not stupid enough to believe that my party is without sin and has never made mistakes. I am one of the few who says that very publicly on as many occasions as I can. I have been elected for 20 years. I have never asked anybody to vote for me yet. I tell them what I think. They match that up against their own best self-interest and they make the decisions.
The member is inviting me to castigate my friends at Queen's Park. I have already done that. It would not be new if I said something nasty about Bob Rae. I will offer this as a matter for your consideration.
I spoke last week to the Treasurer of Ontario briefly, an old friend of mine. He admits quite readily this is the worst possible time for anybody to try to run a government anywhere in the world. At the end of our conversation my friend, Floyd Laughren, the guy they call Pink Floyd, made some decisions that I know are choking him. I know the man well. I know that he has offered some proposals and that his whole heart is not right in there. He is going to have to make some decisions that he really does not want to have to make. At the end of it all I asked him how he was making out. He said: "Mike, I love it. This is what it is all about. This is what I worked all my political life to do, to try to form a government. I do not

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
control what kind of situation we get, good times, bad times, whatever. I am here doing the things I believe in. The people will judge us. They will say whether you are right or wrong, whether you gave it your best shot or not, and that is what it is all about. That is as good as it gets and no matter what you say, no matter what you do, no matter how nifty your jingo is, that is the truth of it all. We all just have to give it the best shot we can. The people will decide".

Mr. Speaker, before I get into the serious matter of this budget I feel I have to make a comment on the statements of my hon. friend from Oshawa when he said he has never asked anyone to vote for him. I noticed the surprise on the faces of some of my colleagues across the way. I can only say that I certainly do ask the people of Halifax to vote for me. I consider it only polite to do so.
To the business at hand which is the business of this year's budget.
The finance minister said that he wanted to deliver a strong bottom line to Canadians. That is indeed what he has done, particularly to our 1.5 million unemployed Canadians by making unemployment a part of this government's economic policy. In spite of promises made in the last budget by the member from Etobicoke Centre-and the promises were for jobs, jobs, jobs- there is still nothing in this budget to improve job prospects for the 1.5 million Canadians who are unemployed. In fact this government actually admits that unemployment will remain at 10 per cent in this country for two more years, and that is nationally.
I look at two of my colleagues on the other side, one from St. John's East and the other from the South Shore. I know, as do they, that unemployment in their ridings is a whole lot higher than 10 per cent.
What this government is essentially asking Canadians is to put their lives on hold. Even worse than putting their lives on hold, it is asking Canadians to watch their lives go down the tubes.
