speechtext: It won't work in Halifax with that nice new contract.

The contract that begins in 1993? My hon. friend talks about the new contract for Halifax. I presume he is talking about the contract to build the coastal patrol vessel. They are supposed to commence in 1993 and heaven knows, that every loyal Nova Scotian prays that that contract will come into being. Indeed that contract should have been given out six or seven years ago. We might now have a coastal patrol vessel that could go out and do some good work on the nose and tail of the Grand Banks, as my hon. friend from St. John's East knows.
As my hon. friend from the South Shore knows the problems on the nose and tail of the Grand Banks relate not too distantly to the fact that we do not have the ships that can go out there to enforce our fisheries law.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext: Tell us about the cuts in the Armed Forces that the Liberals made.
Oh, for the Trudeau years, if only they were back, and back they will be very soon.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext: They are still with us.

Yes, indeed, the only good thing left in this country are the remnants from those years.
There was no mention of training for the unemployed to allow them to re-enter the work force. For those of us who represent Atlantic Canada where we have seen the fish plants close, where we have seen in my usually economically fairly sound riding of Halifax 800 jobs gone with the closure of the Sears catalogue shopping centre, with the threatened closures at Imperial Oil in Dartmouth, with closures up and down the provinces of New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland, one would have thought that somebody in this government might have given a moment's consideration to people who not only have no jobs but who have under this government's policy no reasonable hope for a job in the near future.
You know what the theory is, Mr. Speaker? I will tell you what the theory of this government is. The theory of this government is move or starve. That theory is the one they want to put into force in Atlantic Canada. I should think that my colleagues on the other side of this Chamber who represent Atlantic Canadian constituencies would feel just as bad about this as I do. I would not mind hearing from them on that score.
March 23, 1992

In fact, the federal government, in not mentioning training for the unemployed to allow them to re-enter the work force, cut $100 million from the Canadian Jobs Strategy Program, this strategy which is aimed at improving employment training to immigrants, to the disabled and to those people who have been forced upon the welfare rolls in this country. Those are the people, those are the ones with the least hope and this government has cut out for them any possibility of hope for a job in the near future or even, at least until an election, the distant future.
Poppycock.
Codswallop is better.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext: Who wrote your speech?

I write my own speeches, unlike the member for South Shore.
A lot of these people are now relying on social assistance because their eligibility under unemployment insurance has been exhausted. Why has their eligibility under unemployment insurance been exhausted? I will tell you why. Because this government has taken the unemployment insurance program, particularly in Atlantic Canada, where Atlantic Canadians from the South Shore and from Newfoundland depend upon a seasonal economy and depend upon unemployment insurance for part of their yearly income, and it has gutted it. Gutted it. That is what this government has done. It has gutted it. That number of Canadians forced upon the unemployment rolls and then upon the social assistance rolls can only rise. That is the tragedy that we are facing in this country in 1992. Tory times are tough times.
Coupled with this, there is nothing in the budget to get the economy going again, no strategy to improve our competitiveness. What do we hear from this government all the time? We hear about being competitive. We hear about Canadians being challenged to be competitive. No one in this House, I think, denies that Canadians, given a true level playing field, can be as competitive as people in any other country. It does not mean being competitive with the thought of going into some kind of continental free trade deal with workers who work under ghastly conditions for $1 a day or 30 cents an hour.
Government Orders
You sound like a socialist. What nonsense.

The hon. minister says: "What nonsense".
I wish the hon. minister would put his money where his mouth is and tell me what his plans are to start this economy moving again. It is stalled and he knows it is stalled.
It has moved. It has moved.

Yes, moving down. That is where it is moving.
The government speaks of an ever-changing global economy and the need for a highly skilled work force, but it has chosen to abandon those programs that would set us on the road to becoming a truly competitive nation. Thousands of Canadian jobs are moving south of the border, thousands. In the province of Ontario, in the province of Quebec, they are moving, they are gone. In the other provinces, thousands of people are going as well.
Last week I talked to a young doctor in Halifax who would be a stellar addition to the medical profession wherever she chose to practice. She came to see me, among other things, to tell me that she was leaving to go to the United States. Why is she leaving to go to the United States? Because she is overtaxed, because her equally well educated husband cannot find a job. She is working 18 hours a day and, as she says, has no time to see her children. It is no life, so she is leaving for the United States where she can have a more normal life, where her husband will find employment and where she will see her children.
What is this government doing about this kind of brain drain? Not one thing. Thousands of jobs are moving south of the border, thousands of jobs out of Atlantic Canada moving to central Canada or south of the border. Agencies shut down. ICOT in Nova Scotia shut down. The Science Council shut down, the Economic Council shut down. If we are so concerned about training and education and competitiveness, why is this government cutting off its own nose to spite its face?
It is not sensible. It is not rational and it does not portray any kind of foresight on the part of this government. The government has done major damage to post-secondary education in this country by its cuts to

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
Established Programs Financing. Universities in this country-I spoke on this last week-are suffering. My hon. colleague from St. John's knows that the universities in Atlantic Canada are suffering particularly. Dal-housie University had to raise the tuition for its hard-pressed students by 10 per cent this year. Students no longer can make anything close to the money they used to be able to make in the summertimes to even begin to pay their tuition fees, if there were any jobs, which there aren't, so there is no chance for them at all.
I turn to housing in this budget. The home buyers plan, modelled, I must congratulate the government, after the Liberal Party's own proposals, allows first-time home buyers to withdraw up to $20,000 from their RRSPs for down payments on a home. It is expected that the purchase of a home will have an important ripple effect in the manufacturing and construction industry. Approximately 100,000 holders of RRSPs are expected to take advantage of this opportunity. However this move, good as it is in the sector that it helps, will do nothing to improve the housing situation for those that do not have RRSPs and depend on federal aid.
Cuts to the social housing budget mean that funds available for new units will decrease by 50 per cent in three years.
Who of us in this House has not seen on the streets of our major cities the homeless. Who of us, in our constituency offices, has not dealt with single parents looking for decent, affordable housing for themselves and their children? Who of us has not seen women, having left an abusive situation, desperately seeking second stage housing for themselves and for their children to maintain a safe environment.
What is this government doing? It is decreasing the funds available for new units by 50 per cent. Where is the compassion? Where is even the rationale? Is it just throw everybody out on the heap and hope that the fittest will survive?
I suggest that the members of the government should look to their laurels because their own survival is pretty shaky, based on this kind of government policy.
In 1991, $91 million was available for new social housing units. In 1992-93 that went down to $70 million. In 1993 to 1996, only $45 million will be available.
To a lot of people that sounds like a huge amount of money. But it is less than half of what was available last year. We still see more and more of the homeless on the streets of our cities. We still see the under-housed, we hear the complaints, the pleas from people looking for a decent place to live.
Is there anyone in this House who does not believe that all Canadians deserve a decent place to live? Or is their response "let them eat cake"? I am afraid that we know what the response is.
Another casualty of this year's budget on housing is the elimination of the co-operative housing program, which provided non-profit co-operative housing to low and moderate income families. In Nova Scotia alone, this program enabled 2,000 families to secure housing.
Co-operative housing got its start in the province of Nova Scotia, through the efforts of Monsignor Moses Coady and Father James Tompkins of the famed Anti-gonish movement. Co-operative housing and the co-operatives in Canada in general started in Antigonish many years ago, and it is something that all Canadians have come to understand. It is a good program, it is a solid program, it gives people the opportunity to own their own houses and to have the right and pride of ownership.
What has this government done? It has decimated this program. It has obliterated this program. It says: "Nope, sorry, we don't care any more and we are not going to give you this opportunity".
The members on the opposite side should hang their heads in shame. But, mind you, their heads have been hanging so low for so long it's probably hard to tell. It is all in the degree of angle.
This government claims that the lowering of the personal surtax will result in lower taxes. Certainly it will, for high income earners. This only translates into a $2 dollar a year saving for a family of four with a combined income of $15,000. For families with incomes above $40,000, the so-called tax cut amounts to $44 a year. Some tax break.
Canada is facing serious problems and this budget leaves me wondering if the government is even aware of what it is doing. Unemployment, overfishing, low com-
March 23, 1992

modity prices, plant closures, violent crime, drug abuse, hunger, homelessness and more; the list goes on. There is nothing in this budget that deals with any of these problems. This is a government that says: "Do not tell me about it. I do not want to deal with it. I do not want to know about it. Canadians can fish or cut bait". That is not the only thing they are going to cut come the next election.
We have another thing in this budget that relates to education and it is the fact that this government is trying to deceive Canadians by reducing the student's taxable income by $20 a month while at the same time increasing student debt loads. Continuing to charge the GST on books-GST on books, imagine. Let us just stop and think about that for a minute. A tax on learning, a tax on reading in Canada-appalling. It is no wonder I cannot catch the eye of anybody on the other side of the House. They must be ashamed and rightly so.
The government is continuing the regressive 3 per cent surcharge on student loans. That, in particular, is a scandal. As I said before, it is impossible for students in this country today to earn the money during vacation or with part-time jobs to pay their tuition, to keep themselves going. Therefore, what is post-secondary education becoming in this country? It is becoming a privilege of the wealthy.
I come from a part of the country where there are wealthy people, middle income people and poor people. But I also come from a part of the country where for many years, most of them under Liberal governments, post-secondary education was a viable goal for the children of fishermen, the children of farmers and the children of coal miners and steelworkers in every region of Atlantic Canada, the children of plant workers in northern New Brunswick. Is it a viable goal today? No it is not. It is a viable goal for the children of the upper middle class and even then it is a pretty rough go.
Putting a tax of 3 per cent on student loans is shocking. It is absolutely shocking on the part of a government that talks about competitiveness, training and then in the end pays little more than lip service to the exigencies of getting an education in Canada in the 1990s. Starting with the new loans made for the 1992-93 academic year, the government will cancel the sue month interest free
Government Orders
post-graduation period for students with Canada student loans.
I would make a bet that for a significant number of people in this House, the baby-boomers in this House and there are a fair number of us, we all took advantage of that six-month post-graduation period in which to get ourselves started and under way before we started paying the interest on our student loans. Are the graduates of today less worthy than we were of getting a small break from their government, especially when they have the 3 per cent surcharge to deal with currently?
This regressive measure will increase the debt load of poorer students who rely on Canada student loans to get an education. It will probably put a university education beyond their grasp, absolutely. Some ability to compete! Some ability to make Canada and give Canadian students a level playing field.
Measures introduced by this government since 1986 will result in a $1.6 billion cut in federal support for post-secondary education in 1992-93 and a cumulative cut from 1986 to 1993 of $4.9 billion. Let us look at this compared with the reality of obtaining a post-secondary education. In Nova Scotia, tuition fees have jumped 24 per cent in 1991, and as I mentioned before, are set to rise another 10 per cent this coming fall.
Since 1985-86, tuition fees at Dalhousie have risen by
49.7	per cent. The average cost of room and board rose by $1,200.1 could go on and on and on. We all could go on and on and on, but the bottom line-the Minister of Finance has talked about a bottom line budget-is that this budget does nothing to help Canadians who need it most.
It does nothing to jump-start the economy. It does nothing to retrain people crying for jobs, and it does nothing to make Canada competitive and to give Canadians a level playing field in a down-sized economy. This budget is a sham, a scandal and a disgrace.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the hon. member for her lesson in economics. It was a most interesting one.
She left out some details however. It may, indeed, be true that we do not have enough dollars to pay for every whim and fancy of every single Canadian across the country. The member also mentioned that she would like

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
to see us kick-start the economy, but what she did not tell us is how much she would like to borrow in order to do some of the things that she talked about.
How much money would she borrow, where would she get it from and at what cost to Canadian taxpayers? They are already paying 35 cents out of every tax dollar they send to Ottawa to service the debt accumulated by previous governments that the hon. member is very, very familiar with. They are from the past, before 1984.
I guess my question would be: Where does this money come from to pay for all of the things that Canadians would dearly like to have and to pay for all the things that Canadians enjoyed even though they could not afford them in the past? How would the hon. member raise the funds for this? Would she raise taxes?
This government in its recent budget reduced taxes. At least, if it is not a huge amount of money, it is a step in the right direction. It shows a commitment that this government has to reducing the over-all tax burden on ordinary Canadians, a tax burden that Canadians are telling us they no longer can support.
It is not a matter any longer of governments using politically popular programs to re-elect themselves by spending taxpayers' dollars. Taxpayers simply will not accept that.
Perhaps the hon. member could tell us how she would support all of these programs without increasing taxes, without increasing the burden of debt on the taxpayer and somehow, without being cynical and buying votes, how she would do these things?

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted that the hon. member for Winnipeg has asked me those questions.
I would just like to begin with a comment that I think Canadians know what it is they can no longer support. They are not some of the things that the hon. member was talking about.
I would also like to make a comment on her statement about education being a whim and a fancy. If she thinks that young people, desiring to get a higher education in this country, are the subjects of whim and fancy, then I
am even more frightened for the future of this country while this government stays in power.
Let us get to the meat of the question. The question was: What would I do? How would I pay for it? First of all, we have an unfair tax system in this country. The tax system is all skewed up. This government's people said that when they were in opposition, lo these eight years ago. It is a terrible tax system. It is all fouled up and it is all wrong. It ought to be changed.
This government is in power and has been in power for eight years. What has it done to change the unfairness of the tax system in this country? Zippo. Nothing. This is the government that brought us the GST. That is what it did to change things. It put a tax on the poor and on children. It put a tax on reading, it put a tax on essentials. What did it do to make the tax system in Canada fairer? Not one thing. Nothing.
Make the tax system fairer, that is what my hon. friend needs to do. If she has influence with this government of hers, let us see it done before the next election.
The other thing she said is that the government cut taxes. I thought I dealt with that in my speech. I am sure my colleague from Cape Breton Highlands-Canso heard me do so. I am sure I did.
I will repeat this very slowly so that the hon. member hears me.
If you have an income of $15,000 per year and a family of four, you are part of a group into which all too many Canadians fall. This step in the right direction that my hon. friend talks about is worth $2 per year. I am not sure what exactly you could buy for a family of four, GST included, for $2. Perhaps the hon. member can enlighten me. If you have an income of over $40,000, a median income for a family of four, you get $44. I wonder if anybody, including the hon. member, could enlighten me as to what kind of a spending spree you could go on with $44, again GST included.
This goes past the realm of incompetence. I am shocked that the hon. member would put such a naive question. I am shocked that she would insult the intelligence of Canadians to such a degree.
I for once am speechless.
March 23, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I just want to mention that the hon. member did not answer the question about how she would pay for additional programs spending. She talks about a fairer tax system but I wonder. She does not tell us what that might be. She does not tell us why her government in previous years did not create that system when it had control of this country for most of this century.
I would also suggest to the hon. member that in addition to cutting taxes in this recent budget, the federal government created better opportunities for lower income families through a new child tax credit that gives the lowest income families about $1,700 per year, which is quite a bit of money. You could do quite a bit more than the hon. member pretends. Those people benefit all the way round, lower taxes plus a higher child credit.
The hon. member could perhaps answer my question. Perhaps she does not have an answer. If she does not, maybe she does not want to stand up. She has said she is speechless and perhaps she will remain that way. My question was: How would the hon. member raise the kind of money that it would take to do some of the things that she has suggested in her speech and that Canadians would like to see done? She should share this with us. All members in this House would like to be able to provide all kinds of services to Canadians, but we need to have the money to do this.
Fix the tax system.

Simply saying a fairer tax system is not going to provide that kind of money. If you take from one part of the tax system and add burdens to the other part of the tax system, you do not raise more money. Perhaps the hon. member has a magical solution, a magical formula that she has not told anybody yet. We have not been able to find this answer anywhere else.

Mr. Speaker, I can tell my hon. friend from Winnipeg South that step one in the magical formula is issue the writ.
Step two in the magical formula is bring on-
You haven't any.
speakername: Mr. Walter Van  De Walle@St. Albert

speechtext:
Absolutely. Step two is the change in the tax system. The hon. member's party has been eight years in government. I realize that she like myself
Government Orders
arrived in 1988. If the hon. member has no ideas as to how to reform the tax system and she wants to know what the Liberal ideas are about reforming the tax system, can I tell her that should she wish to cross the floor, we will take it under advisement and consider it. I am sure my hon. colleague the Whip could give her a decision. Then she could become privy to the stellar policies of the Liberal Party of Canada.
She wants to talk about jump-starting the economy. I will say this very slowly so that I will not be misunderstood and so everyone, even the hon. member for St. John's East, can understand it. Hear me. We have been telling this government for months now of one, only one project, that would make a difference to this economy, that would jump-start it and start pumping some money into it. That is the infrastructure project. How many times I ask my hon. colleague for Cape Breton Highlands-Canso, how many times I ask my hon. colleague for Sudbury, have we suggested this to the government, how many times have we said that this is a major giant step to turning this country and its economy around?
I do not know what we can do, not having the government's budget for self-aggrandizement through advertising in newspapers. Again I say it. I say it now. The infrastructure project, think about it. It is a good idea, just like the RRSP idea was a good idea as long as you do not kill it in the second half of the puzzle.
The hon. member says to me: "What ideas?" Our ideas are put forward every day. I have given a few here and now. I have said what can be done. I have spent three and one-half years telling this government what it can do. Is it any wonder I am depressed when it does not listen to me and when it does not take my advice. Even someone as effervescent as myself can get depressed at the response from this government.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to take part in this debate of third reading of Bill C-61, an act to provide borrowing authority for the government.
When Canadians go to the bank and ask to have credit extended, the banker wants to know how they are doing financially and what their intentions are for repayment. It is important that we parliamentarians, before we authorize the government to borrow money, see what

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
the government is doing and where the government is going with their economic and financial policies.
In fact, in the past two weeks Canadians have witnessed both the presentation of the budget and the tabling of the estimates. Together they are the primary tools used by the government to enunciate its fiscal, economic and social policies.
The budget is the major statement of the economic direction which the government intends to follow. Last February in this House the government demonstrated to Canadians its intent to continue to follow the road to economic hardship and high unemployment.
We do not have to go through the whole book; we just have to look, for example, at unemployment predictions. For the coming year the government is predicting the same high unemployment rate that we have right now. Therefore, that concludes that the government intends to follow the same direction that produced record layoffs and record bankruptcies.
Just prior to tabling his budget, the Minister of Finance qualified his budget as being realistic, in other words, a budget conceived with today's economic reality in mind. Canadians can only conclude that the minister must have been in another world when he dreamed up his latest budget.
Today a Gallup poll came out on the budget. Only 23 per cent of Canadians believe that the budget is going to do something to help the economy.
If the minister wants to discuss reality, I would tell him that the reality is that 1.5 million Canadians are out of work. The reality is that over 13,000 businesses and
62,000	consumers went bankrupt in 1991. The reality is that Canadians are taxed more today than in any other period in history. The reality is that both business and consumer confidence in the economy is at an all-time low. That is the economic reality in which we find ourselves today.
The problem is that the Conservative government has failed once again to face the reality and address the most important issues. For the minister to acknowledge that the unemployment rate would remain over 10 per cent, as I said before, for the next fiscal period is irresponsible.

Obviously Canadians are going to be suspicious when the Minister of Finance says he intends to follow the same path as his predecessor. Consider what happened since last year's budget was brought down. A year ago the Minister of Finance at the time rose in the House to read his budget speech. I would like to quote just one sentence from Hansard of February 26, 1991. The minister said:
This budget sets out a Plan for Economic Recovery-a strong,
confident recovery that not only puts the recession behind us but
leads us forward to continuing growth and renewed prosperity.
Let us look at the programs set out in this budget, the one used by the Minister of Finance today, and we will see that he has not succeeded in leading us to a period of renewed prosperity. We will see that we are far from prosperity. All that the Conservative government's economic program has been able to create is a long list of victims. The victims to whom I refer are the 62,277 Canadian consumers and 13,495 Canadian companies that went bankrupt in 1991. That is an increase of 39 per cent over the previous year. That is far from the road to prosperity promised by the Minister of Finance.
I also refer to the 1.5 million unemployed Canadians and I do not count those who are no longer looking for work because they are discouraged, like many jobless people. The Conservatives' economic policies have not been able to create prosperity in Quebec either. Indeed the province of Quebec lost 68,000 jobs in 1991 and another 4,000 in January 1992. In Quebec 18,319 consumers and 5,217 businesses went bankrupt in 1991. Officially Quebec now has 405,000 unemployed, not counting those who have given up looking for work.
In Montreal the average unemployment rate in 1991 was 12.2 per cent, an increase of 2 per cent over the year before. This negative trend does not seem to end, since unemployment in Montreal rose to 12.4 per cent in February 1992. The government is ignoring the importance of Montreal's economic well-being for Quebec and all of Canada.
The metropolitan area provides nearly half the employment in the province. Unfortunately, according to a recent report, one adult in two in the Montreal region does not work. This is intolerable, in what is one of Canada's major metropolitan areas.
March 23, 1992

Last year was one of the worst for tourism in the Montreal area, and tourism is not the only sector that is crumbling under the Conservatives. The manufacturing sector in Montreal has also been hard hit.
As the member for Saint-Leonard, a riding where manufacturing plays an important role, I know that eastern Montreal is dying. For 10 years, the number of plant closings and job losses has been very high. We lost 900 jobs when Angus closed down; 380 at Vickers; 900 at Welfab steel products; 500 at Esso; 450 at Gulf; 591 at Steinberg, and the list goes on, Mr. Speaker.
Montreal is on its death bed, with 10,000 more unemployed workers than in 1986. Despair, that is what the Conservative path has led to.
And on top of that, the latest budget does nothing to stimulate job creation in this country. How can we get the economy back on track, when more than 10 per cent of the community is not working, according to official statistics? We proposed a plan to modernize infrastructures. It was a five-point plan, and the government is to be commended for having accepted and implemented two of them, but a week later, interest rates went up again. When people are ready to withdraw $20,000 from their Registered Retirement Savings Plan to buy a house, do you really expect them to when all of a sudden interest rates go up again? This has just destroyed any motivation they had. That is why the economic situation in Montreal continues to be a disaster.
Everyone agrees that to get the country out of this slump we must get consumers to spend. However they are not spending, either because they are unemployed or they are working but their purchasing power is going down. Every weekend we see people cross the border because it is cheaper. Of course the government's high dollar policy does not help.
In fact what the minister gives with one hand he takes away with the other. For instance, a couple with a combined income of $40,000 and two children will receive $44 annually in family allowance. Lest we forget, on January 1, 1991 the GST came into effect. On July 1 our unemployment insurance premiums went up by 24 per cent. According to Statistics Canada we are more heavily taxed today than at any time in our history. I do not remember exactly how many new taxes this government introduced.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: It being two o'clock, the House will now proceed with statements by members pursuant to Standing Order 31.

Mr. Speaker, certain documents released last week, which had been kept secret since 1970, confirmed that clandestine action was taken by Pierre-Elliott Trudeau's Liberal cabinet against Quebec and many Quebec citizens who at the time were considered to be dangerous nationalists.
This unworthy behaviour was an insult to the good faith and intelligence of Quebecers and all Canadians who expected dignity, integrity and justice from their elected representatives.
It is not surprising that these same leaders arbitrarily implemented the War Measures Act that violated the rights of hundreds of Quebecers and stained Canada's reputation as a democracy. It is inconceivable that such leaders held such an attitude against Canadians, all the while claiming to defend democracy.
I do not accept that.

Mr. Speaker, many of my constituents in Hamilton Mountain have been asking me about the GST, the debt and the deficit. They would like to be assured that GST revenues will not be spent on pre-election goodies.
Last year the government introduced Bill C-21 which calls for all GST revenues to be directed toward deficit reduction. After receiving second reading this bill has been sitting in committee for quite some time. We are waiting to see if the Conservatives practise what they preach on the importance of reducing the deficit. Canadians what to know: Is the government still committed to this legislation?

March 23, 1992

Recently released documents have linked the cabinet of Pierre Trudeau to the RCMP theft of Parti Quebecois lists. This is as shocking as it is appalling, to think that any government would use a national police force in this fashion.
In this new age of constitutional committees and conferences, royal commissions and the involvement of ordinary Canadians in nation building by the Prime Minister, Gestapo tactics like those used by the Tru-deauites are unthinkable; the October crisis, falsely arresting people, using the RCMP to steal, gathering political information through criminal tactics. Remember what Trudeau said when asked how far he would go: "Watch me", he said. We are still watching, and it makes you wonder what other dirty secrets are in the closet of history.
When Trudeau comes to comment on today's attempts to heal Canada, fractured in 1980, Canadians will wonder how a man who used his office to abuse and deny Canadians their rights could now possibly utter a single word in defence of either rights or freedoms.

Environmental assessment became a hot potato in Quebec over the weekend. Development, regardless of its impact on the environment, has been the trademark of Liberals in Quebec for decades. Take, for example, the flooding caused by the hydroelectric projects James Bay I and H, a total of 25,824 square kilometres. This is six times as much land flooded by one project as is protected by all the provincial and national parks in Quebec combined.
The Brundtland World Commission on the Environment recommends 12 per cent protection as a minimum. Quebec has 0.3 per cent protected lands.
The Quebec Liberal Party voted unanimously over the weekend to "denounce and condemn federal environmental assessment Bill C-13". The great Liberal tradition of being firmly on both sides of every issue was confirmed by all Liberal MPs voting for Bill C-13. Not
unlike the weekend remarks of former Prime Minister Trudeau about the Liberal decision to steal the membership lists of the Parti Quebecois, "the record is there; that is all I can say". The member for Vancouver Quadra was the Minister of Justice at the time and Leader of the Opposition was in cabinet. Let us hear from them today.

Mr. Speaker, this past week a very significant group of parliamentarians met in Vancouver to discuss our role as parliamentarians in relationship to the environment, particularly as it relates to increasing urbanization and development of megacities. There were about 150 delegates representing 60 countries from both developed and developing countries. The meeting resulted in acceptance and publication of the Vancouver Declaration of Global Parliamentarians and Habitat on Human Settlements and Sustainable Development.
I congratulate the hon. member for Fraser Valley West on his election as chairman of this body and also the member for Ottawa West on her selection as a member of the executive because of her hard work and leadership on women's issues.
We anticipate more good work from this exciting body.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the problem of dangerous sexual offenders is one that requires action on the part of the government. Convicted sex offenders are sentenced to a term in penitentiary at the conclusion of which they are released into the community. Psychologists and specialists in deviant behaviour know that the likelihood of repetition of the offence is very great. The police know that nothing can be done to restrain the offender until he has reoffended. Another victim and another penitentiary sentence.
Surely it is time to devise a new means of dealing with and treating these offenders. Surely the criminal justice system is ill equipped to protect our children and stop these crimes.
March 23, 1992

I urge the government to look at the possibility of special treatment facilities for such individuals to protect the defenceless in our society and try to provide some help for these disfigured criminals who cause us all such anguish and hurt.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have with me today a petition signed by some 14,700 residents of southwest Nova Scotia from Shelburne County through to Digby County. It is my intention to present this petition later today to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
They express a concern of the people of southwest Nova Scotia over the possibility that the search and rescue helicopter service which has saved over 40 lives over the course of the past three years will be removed from Yarmouth.
Yesterday some 300 people met at the Yarmouth airport together with municipal, provincial and federal politicians to express their concern and to urge the government not to allow an end to the vitally important search and rescue and fisheries surveillance service.
I join with those residents in urging the government to find the means to ensure that this service remains in place for the benefit of fishermen and their families in southwestern Nova Scotia.

Mr. Speaker, something must be done about the terrible plight of the Canadian forces auxiliary vessel Riverton based in Halifax and crewed by civilian employees of DND.
Repeated pleas by the crew of this vessel have fallen on deaf ears and they paint a sad picture. Cramped quarters, obsolete machinery and inhuman working conditions face these men on the Riverton every minute they are at sea. They have consulted with management and heard nothing. They have complained to management and were told that if they continued to complain they might lose their jobs.
Eight men live in a space that is suitable for two people. There is no recreational space. Fourteen men
must eat in a mess the size of a closet. How long will the government allow this situation to continue?
The Riverton is vital to the TRUMP program and to the frigate program but the government makes repeated promises for a refit that never takes place.
The government must keep its promise to refit the Riverton this spring. The top priority must be the installation of adequate crew facilities so that the crew can feel like humans rather than animals.

Mr. Speaker, the federal government is currently negotiating to buy 50 EHI 101 helicopters from European Helicopters Industries Ltd. in England. Part of the negotiations include a requirement that EHI contract out to Canadian manufacturers for components of equal value to the main contract. Further, Atlantic Canada is to receive 10 per cent of the opportunities provided from these industrial benefits.
It is very important that these guidelines be met and that companies like IMP Aerospace in Amherst, Nova Scotia be given the opportunity to contract for these helicopter components. IMP was recently awarded the AQAP-1 quality recognition from the Department of National Defence which qualifies it as an outstanding manufacturer of airplane components and is now recognized world-wide. In addition, IMP Aerospace from Amherst has also qualified for the Boeing D1900 quality approval certification.
It is most appropriate that this factory have the opportunity to bid on this work considering that it was one of the industries most severely impacted from the termination of the tracker program.
I call on the various departments of government involved to ensure that Atlantic Canada gets its fair share.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this past week the New Brunswick NDP Federal Council of Ridings, while meeting in Moncton, passed a resolution congratulating the workers at the Stone Consolidated Paper Mill in Bathurst. I was

March 23, 1992
pleased to attend this meeting along with our New Brunswick leader, MLA Elizabeth Weir.
Threatened with wage rollbacks and closure, with no guarantees, the workers headed by Mr. Rick Doucet of the Canadian Paperworkers Union held to their position. Their fear was that to capitulate to Stone would have given this industry a beachhead on which to attack the workers who work in this industry which is facing many problems today.
In a statement the union says that this is not a problem created by workers. The New Brunswick workers are well qualified and hard working. We ask that corporate Canada be as responsible as the workers of Bathurst.

Mr. Speaker, the world is rapidly recognizing that atmospheric pollution must be stopped. It is also recognizing that nuclear power will play a major role in achieving that result.
Canada has a significant contribution to offer through our global leadership in nuclear plant design and operation, particularly with development of the Candu III reactor.
In turn my own province of New Brunswick is in a position to create lasting industrial development by seizing the opportunity to build our existing nuclear energy experience to become Canada's centre of excellence in Candu III manufacturing and marketing. This is potential of a world scale.
The nuclear opportunity for New Brunswick may be fleeting. Competition is already in the wings. New Brunswick should act now.

Mr. Speaker, March 21 marked the anniversary of the Shar-peville massacre and as a result was proclaimed as the international day for the elimination of racial discrimination by the United Nations.
It is celebrated this year at a very timely moment with the encouraging results in the South African referendum.
But we need not go as far as Africa to look at how we correct racial discrimination. We must look at ourselves at home. We can look at the police files against Haitians. We can look at the difficulties experienced by visible minorities in their job search. We can look at the attacks on refugees and immigrants. We can look at the notorious hate literature campaign and certainly the discrimination experienced by aboriginals in our court system.
As an antidote to these events I would like to commend the constructive initial responses by the Citizenship Council of Manitoba which this year distributed
130,000	"No to Racism" stickers throughout the schools and among 90 citizens' groups.
It is a way of showing how the community can draw awareness to the issue of racism and giving individuals the opportunity to express their personal opposition.
In a recent survey multiculture-

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to congratulate the University of Calgary law school team which won first place in the Canadian division of the Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition. The competition involved nearly all the law schools in Canada. It was held in Saskatoon on February 1 and 2. Members of the University of Calgary team are Jonathan Blakey, Leslie Morris, Hilary Stout, Kerri-Anne Thomas, and Kevin Zemp.
The Jessup competition presents students with an international law problem which they are then required to debate in front of the International Court of Justice. To score well takes considerable finesse and skill. The competition provides a forum for students to practise their debating and analytical skills.
As the Canadian champions the University of Calgary team will travel to Washington, D.C., on March 28 to April 4 for the international round of competition. Approximately 30 countries will be participating.
March 23, 1992

As second place winner of the Canadian finals, the team from McGill University will also be going to Washington.
On behalf of my constituents in Calgary Southeast and my hon. colleagues here today in the House I would like to wish both teams the best of luck.

Mr. Speaker, there is another nail in the coffin of the government's so-called prosperity initiative. Remember that one? It included promoting education and training, doubling the number of scientists, mathematicians and engineers and so on.
Friday when he thought no one was looking the Minister of State for Youth, instead of the usual press conference, sneaked out a bad news news release on the summer employment program called Challenge '92.
After $9 billion in cutbacks have increased college and university fees by as much as 150 per cent, after making student loans more difficult and expensive to repay, and after engineering a recession where youth unemployment has risen to almost 20 per cent, the government announced another cut in real dollars for student summer jobs.
Now funding is only 40 per cent of what it was in 1985 in real dollars and only half as many students will be supported.
Now instead of filling classrooms more youth are filling unemployment lines. That is really some prosperity initiative.

Mr. Speaker, the three words made in Canada mean quality. Made in Canada creates jobs. Made in Canada shows the world that we mean business.
I urge the federal government to initiate a nation-wide program promoting made-in-Canada products. This campaign, supported by retailers, manufacturers and government is to remind consumers that first-rate prod-
Oral Questions
ucts are available and being produced here in Canada. A campaign to buy made in Canada will create and maintain jobs for Canadians and boost the economy. This would be a win-win situation.
I urge all Canadians to support made-in-Canada products and look for these three words when they shop.
speakername: Mr. Walter Van  De Walle@St. Albert

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in 1989 when the Minister of Transport announced huge cuts to VIA Rail services, he promised that for the particularly remote regions we would maintain nine so-called remote routes in the national transportation system so that citizens who do not have other means of transport could still travel.
Now we are seeing the same government go back on that promise. VIA Rail has decided not service some stops between Capreol and Armstrong, Ontario. These stops are valued by tourist operators, cottagers, out-doorsmen and native people who have no other access to the lands.
These cuts are negatively affecting the people who least deserve it. For one tourist resort owner, this cut in service means the train will stop two miles past his resort. Customers must walk back along the track two miles winter and summer. This inconvenience is occurring all along the track and is just one more example of how the chances for northern development have been weakened at a time when they should be strengthened.
['Mr. Speaker, I would like to designate tomorrow, March 24, an allotted day.']

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
Two weeks ago in Toronto, speaking of trade disputes, the Prime Minister accused the United States of acting like a tin pot dictator. We all saw him on television and boy, was he going to be tough. He told Canadian auto workers that he would stand up for them. Last week, when he was in New York, he said that trade disputes

March 23, 1992
Oral Questions
were "low-level harassment by functionaries in the administration".
Why did the Prime Minister talk tough in Toronto and wimp out on Wall Street?
Speaking of wimps, how have you all been while I was away?
Oh, oh.

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend has of course again, and no doubt inadvertently mislead the House. What I indicated in Toronto was exactly what I indicated in New York. There was no change at all in a statement made in Toronto as opposed to a statement made in New York.
If my hon. friend would like to take the time before she asks her next question to consult and then table both transcripts, I know she would want to do so with an apology.

Mr. Speaker, the person who should be tendering an apology is the Prime Minister who did not stand up for Canadian jobs when he was in New York.
I would like to quote him directly. This is what he said: "I said low-level functionaries. I won't go any further than that. It's not President Bush. It's not his cabinet".
I want to ask the Prime Minister this question. If it is just a couple of low-level functionaries, why have the issues not been resolved and why has the American government not dropped actions on softwood lumber and Hondas?

Mr. Speaker, I have indicated from the very beginning-my hon. friend has made my point. That statement was one I made both in Toronto and New York, that the action taken in the United States was not an action initiated by the President of the United States.
My hon. friend from Newfoundland is chuckling. That just indicates ignorance. The fact of the matter is that this action was not initiated by the President of the United States. It was initiated by lobby groups who attacked the American administration which then, at the level of low-level functionaries, responded with an action that damaged very seriously the interests of Canada. It was at that point I indicated that if this kind of action had come from a small country with a tin pot
dictator, that would be one thing but coming from a great trading nation like the United States, this was most unworthy. That I said in Toronto, that I said here and in New York.
Thanks to the free trade agreement, we have initiated-
Oh, oh.
Had it not been for the free trade agreement which gives us-
We are taking it on the chin.
Mr. Speaker, the member for Winnipeg is finding this so entertaining, it is the first laugh he has had in a long time. I will keep it up.
Oh, oh.
Somebody should probably put a stop to that. The right hon. Prime Minister may wish to complete his answer.
He's too embarrassed.

My hon. friend from Winnipeg says that I am too embarrassed. I will acknowledge to him that I would be very embarrassed today if this was the final word in the United States.
That would have been the final word in the United States prior to 1988, but under the free trade agreement we have access to a dispute settlement mechanism, whereas we would have been dead as doornails under the Liberal policy. Under the dispute settlement mechanism, we have won these cases and we will win these cases on behalf of Canada.
Most recently we had a pork decision which affected so vitally the interests of western producers. Had the hon. member from Winnipeg's view prevailed, the western pork producers would have been down the drain. As it was, their case was safe.
Perhaps we should move on. [Translation]

Mr. Speaker, I understand that the Prime Minister is very embarrassed about his change of position between Toronto and New York.

I will ask him a very specific question. He pretends that it is only bureaucrats and functionaries. However, it is the Commerce Department, headed by Carla Hills who is in cabinet with George Bush. So I ask him again why he was not able to solve this problem with his great friend George Bush, since it comes from the U.S. Commerce Department and directly from Carla Hills.

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is again mistaken. The U.S. Commerce Department is not headed by Carla Hills. That is another mistake from the hon. member for Hamilton East.
She was wrong to talk about a flip-flop. It was an error and a lie when she said it in English and it is the same in French.

One moment, please.

The right hon. Prime Minister is suggesting that the question was a lie. I may have misheard it but I would hope that the right hon. gentleman would certainly correct that immediately.

I will be happy. I have already indicated that the statement made by my hon. friend in regard to a quotation was false. It was false when she made it in her first question. It was false in her second and it is false in French.
It is not a direct quote. I have invited my hon. friend to produce both transcripts. When she produces both transcripts, she will see that contrary to what she has indicated, I have said exactly the same thing in New York as I did in Toronto. That will come as a surprise to a Liberal.

I think the difficulty is at least in the translation. The Prime Minister is in the position-according to the translation-of having said that the hon. member's statement was a lie.
That may be inadvertent. It may be a mis-translation, but I would ask the right hon. gentleman to make it very clear to the House that that is not what he intended to say.

Mr. Speaker, I indicated in English, and I gave my hon. friend the benefit of the doubt, that I believe that the mistake was inadvertent.
I indicated very clearly that in my judgment the mistake was probably inadvertent. Notwithstanding the
Oral Questions
very important qualification that I gave my hon. friend, the same error was then repeated again in English and was then repeated again in French. Clearly it was not inadvertent, clearly it is an attempt by my hon. friend to impute to me something that I did not say.
Now if the shoe fits, my hon. friend can wear it.

I wonder if hon. members would leave this to the Chair.
As interpreted, the right hon. gentleman indicated that the member putting the question had said something which is a lie. There is a distinction, of course, between a lie and something that is in error or mistaken or otherwise. All I am asking the right hon. gentleman to do is to assure the House that he did not mean the word "lie".

Mr. Speaker, I will of course withdraw any comment that is at any time unparliamentary. But when the Speaker is examining the record, I know that the Speaker in rendering judgment will want to examine the fact that three times a statement that I affirmed not to be true was repeated by the acting Leader of the Opposition. That was an abuse of Parliament and for that she ought to withdraw.

OLYMPIA & YORK DEVELOPMENT LIMITED

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Finance.
The Canadian Press today quotes Tbm Van Dusen, a spokesman for the Minister of Finance, as confirming that the government has been approached by the Olympia & York Development Limited about possible assistance from the government in the restructuring of that company's debt.
In view of the involvement of a number of major Canadian financial institutions in the affairs of that huge Canadian multinational company, will he inform the House and Canadians of the options under consideration by the government in this important matter?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can confirm to the hon. member that there have been discussions with stakeholders in the Olympia & York company. We have been involved in discussions with the government of Ontario, with financial institutions, both domestically and internationally.

March 23, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Minister of Finance.
I ask him if he has also been in discussion with other governments on this matter. Furthermore, in view of the possible implications and extent of this situation, will the minister undertake today to keep Parliament and Canadians fully informed of all the options under consideration as this serious situation evolves?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the hon. member's interest in this and I know he is expressing his genuine concern.
I indicated earlier that there have been discussions with the government of the province of Ontario. The discussions are ongoing with financial institutions, both internationally and domestically. Of course the discussions are at a stage where no definitive decisions have been made, but obviously at the appropriate time the hon. member and others will certainly be fully apprised of the situation.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
The Minister of National Health and Welfare is quoted today as saying that a social charter as proposed in the Constitution should not be there because we cannot afford it; we cannot afford to provide health care, to feed our citizens, to provide shelter for our citizens.
I want to say that before this government closes the door on the futures of thousands of Canadian children, it should close the door on tax breaks for wealthy Canadians.
We can afford to feed the children of this country. We do not have to give free lunches to corporate executives. Will this government stand up and make a commitment to feeding the poor of this country, the future generations of this country, and cut out the tax breaks for the wealthy who do not need them.

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I answered that question many times last week while the leader of the NDP, I believe for some good reason I suppose, was not in the House of Commons. I can only repeat what I said at the time. I believe we made a good move with the budget and the child benefit. We put in $2 billion over five years. I also said that we should come forward soon with another package concerning children at risk. There are other policies or initiatives which could be announced dealing with the question of children.
In light of what I said with regard to the social charter, I did not say that I was opposed to having a social charter in the Constitution. However, I did say that when we talk about the social charter it is not enough to say that we should guarantee the young people in Canada food and so on, we have to express exactly how we will pay for this because Canadians want to know.
I know that the word resources is not in the vocabulary of the NDP, but it is in mine.

A supplementary, Mr. Speaker, for the Prime Minister.
Surely at this time when we are talking about the unity of our country we have a responsibility, as this Prime Minister and this government committed to in 1989, to eradicate poverty in this country. Yet the Prime Minister's government has abandoned child care, it has abandoned the poor and it has abandoned the unemployed.
I want to ask the Prime Minister now: Will he stand up here today and repudiate the comments that we should not in this country have a social charter that gives some common vision to this country, the common social values that we share, and give some hope to Canadians and hope that we can offer our citizens decency and compassion?

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend says that the government has abandoned child care. That is not the case. That we have abandoned the poor. That is not the case either. That we have abandoned the unemployed. That is not the case either. My hon. friend knows that.
March 23, 1992

I think my hon. friend could make her point without indulging in such misleading rhetoric. There is a point to be made without this constant verbal abuse that in no way reflects reality.
My hon. friend asks a question about the minister of health. The minister of health, as I understand it, has indicated many times that he is not in any way opposed to the idea of a social charter, provided that the social charter in the Constitution involves indicating clearly how we are going to pay for it. Now I know that concept is alien to my hon. friend, but that is the only caveat that the minister of health has placed on it. He is saying that all of these socially desirable goals are fair and we could indeed support them provided my hon. friend will join the House in telling the country how all of these will be funded.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Prime Minister. Seven hundred thousand children and more than two million Canadians do not have enough to eat in this country. That is reality, not rhetoric.
Is the Prime Minister prepared to ensure that the poor have enough to eat and is he going to change the present tax system? A billion dollars of tax money is now being used to pay for businessmen's free lunches. Is the Prime Minister prepared to end this tax system that favours the well-off and instead use these fiscal resources for the less fortunate? Does the Prime Minister have the political will to do that?

Mr. Speaker, between 1984 and 1989, the rate of poverty fell from 18.1 to 13.6 per cent in Canada. The deteriorating economic conditions in 1990 resulted in a higher number of low income people for the first time in seven years. Still, there were 576,000 fewer low income Canadians in 1990 than in 1984 and 123,000 fewer low income children.
Since 1984 the average family income, adjusted for inflation, has increased 9.7 per cent or $4,600 in 1990. Of course we have a serious problem of wealth distribution in Canada, but we are making significant progress on it, as the data show.
Oral Questions
In asking such questions, the hon. member should stop overlooking facts and concentrating on rhetoric. Facts in the end are what govern human behaviour.

Mr. Speaker, this government's own Crown corporation has gone on a $40 million cross-border shopping binge. CN Rail announced today that it is awarding a multi-million dollar contract to build at least 25 locomotives to the General Electric plant in Erie, Pennsylvania.
This decision will cost 1,442 person-years of employment for London, Ontario workers at General Motors Diesel, the Canadian bidder for the job. This decision does not invest in Canadian technology and Canadian workers.
I want to ask the Prime Minister: Where is the buy Canadian policy for Crown agencies? Why is this government not investing in Canadian jobs instead of U.S. jobs?

Mr. Speaker, CN went out on a bid for the construction of 25 locomotives and had to consider these two bids according to their value. Clearly the lowest bidder was General Electric to which the contract has been awarded.
Because of the implications of a number of MPs on this side of the House, namely the minister himself, the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism, as well as the hon. member for London-Middlesex, we worked with CN. As a result of that, there are going to be 50 more locomotives that will be rebuilt by CN for an American railroad and 36 locomotives for export which means that the number of jobs available to Canadians through this contract will be twice as much as it would have been had it been given to GM.

Mr. Speaker, I would hope that the minister tables those commitments and documents, especially if it means Canadian jobs.
London's GM locomotives would contain 61 per cent Canadian content. The employment generated from awarding the contract to General Electric in Pennsylvania would not even be comparable, but while this government is offering jobs to U.S. workers, the buy

Oral Questions
American clauses in the U.S. prevent Canadian companies from bidding on some U.S. contracts.
I want to task this government: Why is this government allowing U.S. firms to bid on government contracts when the Americans will not offer us the same opportunity? Why has this government not objected to the buy American clauses in the United States under the free trade agreement?

Mr. Speaker, I clearly understand that the member was not listening to the answer because I indicated as part of this contract, 50 locomotives are going to be rebuilt by GE in Canada for Burlington Northern U.S. Railroad. As a result of the contract that has been awarded, there will be jobs for suppliers in Winnipeg, Calgary, Hamilton, Welland, Stoney Creek, London, Kingston, Prescott, Belleville, Fort Erie, Sherbrooke, Montreal, St. Laurent and Point Claire.
The total number of PYs involved in this contract is 448. It would have been 257 under the GM contract.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Prime Minister. This year the Canadian government will be paying foreign students and foreign universities $18 million to study Canada. For example, Canadian taxpayers are funding Pennsylvania State University to study social services for senior citizens in metropolitan Toronto. How can the Prime Minister justify funding foreign universities when Canadian colleges and universities are pleading for more money?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speechtext: The minister responsible for the program is away on government business today, but I will certainly bring this matter to his immediate attention on his return.

Mr. Speaker, I will put my supplementary question to the finance minister.
It was his budget that indicates $18 million will be spent to fund foreign students in foreign universities.
How can the Minister of Finance justify eliminating the Court Challenges Program, the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission when it is spending almost the same amount of money to create American jobs and other foreign jobs? Why is his government cross-border shopping for research? Why is he eliminating Canadian jobs and creating foreign jobs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship):
speechtext: The question does not seem to revolve around the Canada Student Loans Program, but certainly, the minister has been working very carefully within the confines of that program. As I indicated to the member, we will get back to him at an early opportunity.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the right hon. Prime Minister on a different topic.
Over the weekend, the Prime Minister gave notice that there were transcripts made public of secret testimony given in 1978 by the former RCMP security division head, John Starnes to the McDonald royal commission on RCMP wrongdoings. These were made public over the weekend.
Those documents may link the former Trudeau cabinet to the 1973 RCMP theft of PQ membership lists and other confidential information.
My question is the following. In addition to this information, is the Prime Minister aware or is the government aware of any other evidence to substantiate or corroborate Mr. Starnes' claim that there was a link between the government of that day and the RCMP theft? If indeed there is such evidence, would the Prime Minister be willing to make it public?

Just a moment. I have great doubts whether that question is in order. First of all, it involves a matter of some years ago and it involves a government other than the government which is here today.
March 23, 1992

I think it is out of order. The hon. member may wish to consider the matter and see whether on a supplemental he can bring it within order.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the right hon. Prime Minister.
Since this is an ongoing concern of Canadians, what actually happened in 1969 to 1973, and in view of the fact the government is responsible for responding in this House to security questions, I want to ask the Prime Minister whether or not there is any other evidence that the Prime Minister can make public regarding what happened back in 1969 to 1973?
With the greatest respect, it seems to me at the moment that that again is out of order. It may be an issue that can be raised in the House, but it will have to come within the rules.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Right Honourable Prime Minister.
Has the United States consented to binding arbitration of the Honda dispute? Yes or No?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend is well aware that I have responded to his question in this regard before.
The matter is subject to discussion between the United States and Canada. It might become a matter of chapter 18 consultation between the federal government and the American government, as is the case with the rules of origin question as it relates to non-mortgage interest with the CAMI operation. If that is the case, then that would be subject to negotiation but it would not be binding.

Mr. Speaker, once again we see how our present trade deal is so inadequate that it leaves Canada wide open to ongoing U.S. trade harassment and to deindustrialization here in Canada.
With a new trade deal imminent, Canadians have a right to know exactly where this government stands. So I put it to the minister. Will he insist on not only greater North American content rules but also Canadian con-
Oral Questions
tent rules that will ensure Canadian auto workers their fair share of North American jobs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on the one hand my hon. friend says that he is anxious to see a satisfactory resolution of the rules of origin question as it relates to Honda, and I am sure the CAMI operation as well.
On the other hand he is saying that we want to have higher rules of origin which would damage those very companies if they were made too high.
The member is shaking his head. If my hon. friend understood the implications of the rules of origin, he would know that if we set the rules of origin in Canada too high they would disqualify some of the transplant operations at this point of their existence.
Possibly down the road that might be appropriate, but this is one of the balances we must take into account in the negotiation of this agreement.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. I want to offer him a chance to clarify the confusion about the purpose and intent of his trip last week to New York.
The Prime Minister went to New York supposedly to give major U.S. and Canadian newspapers Canada's view about the trade harassment being visited upon this country by the United States government.
While there the Prime Minister referred to the trade harassment in question in terms of responsibility, and I am quoting the Prime Minister: "It is not President Bush; it is not his cabinet". The Prime Minister absolved the U.S. President and absolved the U.S. cabinet of any responsibility.
Is the Prime Minister aware, as first minister of this country, that indeed the softwood lumber action was taken against Canada by the U.S. commerce department whose secretary is a member of George Bush's cabinet?
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend has of course the facts quite wrong.

Good point.

March 23, 1992
Oral Questions

Well, he does, Lloyd. He has them completely wrong. The trade harassment issue itself, which we all deplore and which I have denounced very vigorously on behalf of all Canadians, was not initiated by the President of the United States.
Nobody said that.
That is what I said, precisely. If my hon. friend agrees with me that it was not initiated by the President of the United States-
The secretary of commerce.
If it was not initiated by the President of the United States then he is agreeing with the premise of my own statement.

Mr. Speaker, the last time the Prime Minister went to New York it was rumoured he was on a job hunting expedition. This week it looked like he got one as spokesman for the U.S. President, not spokesman for the workers of Canada.
Hear, hear.

I want to ask the Prime Minister again. What is at issue here is not what the Prime Minister said. We know what he said. He absolved the U.S. President and he absolved the U.S. cabinet, all members of the cabinet, of any responsibility for U.S. trade harassment of Canada when in fact it was the secretary responsible for the department of commerce who must have authorized the trade action of the department of commerce against Canada on softwood lumber.
A fact is a fact is a fact, and the Prime Minister saying it is not a fact will not change it.

Mr. Speaker, I did not hear all of that last question. My hon. friend has a tendency to diminish a very valid point with unworthy prefatory comments most times. Because I know him well, I know he will regret it and want to withdraw as soon as he leaves the House.
We are on all fours with my hon. friend. We have taken a vigorous stand on behalf of Canadian producers. The only difference that exists between us is that we are in favour of a free trade agreement which now gives us access to a dispute settlement mechanism, whereas my hon. friend is a member of a political party that will-
Tear it up.
Tear it up, tear up the free trade agreement?
Well, they might renegotiate it.

Renegotiate it? Change it?
Tell us about that, Brian, when you stand up the next time.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport.
I would like the Minister of Transport to explain to this House, and more important to Canadians, how it is that the only way jobs can be created in Canada is by having CN award a contract to a company in Erie, Pennsylvania.

Mr. Speaker, I will try it another time. March 23, 1992

He will not let us use the Black Sea fleet to protect the 200-mile limit.

He has expressed concerns about the manner in which the negotiations have been ongoing. He has indicated the Government of Ukraine is ready to make compromises in the interest of keeping the Commonwealth together, but he feels very strongly that the national interests of Ukraine must be respected as well.
He is looking forward to their next meeting in May, but I suppose in a fundamental way he wanted to convey to all members of the House and to the Canadian people the gratitude of his government for the very significant

assistance that Canada has provided thus far to all initiatives in the former Soviet Union.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. member should have read the regulations. They were pre-published months ago. He had the occasion.
I did.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the same minister.
Increasing numbers of refugee claimants from eastern Europe, from the Hispanic countries and from many other countries are being deported.
They probably would have been considered refugees if their cases had been heard promptly. Now they are being deported because the situation in their homelands has changed while they are stuck in the backlog.

What definition of humanitarian and compassionate grounds does the minister use to justify telling these people to sever their new roots in Canada and go back to a life of uncertainty in their homelands?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:

unstable war-tom corner of the world. A 10-year old Canadian born girl was sent back to Bangladesh with her parents, a country which she has never seen.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in all fairness to Canada and to the Canadian people, whenever someone raises the question of our immigration system in the House and depicts it as being about sending kids, for instance a 10-year-old, out of Canada, the reality is that Canadians are not told that there are hundreds of thousands of immigrants received in Canada according to the rule of law and the regulations.

Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportu-

nities Agency): Mr. Speaker, senior officials from the Department of Fisheries and Oceans have been consulting extensively with all the user groups in New Brunswick and throughout the maritime provinces on these issues.

speechtext:

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour and privilege to present a petition signed by a number of residents in the Thunder Bay area.
The petitioners raise a concern about a previous promise by the government to freeze unemployment insurance premium rates for three years and that recent cumulative increases in the UI premiums are unfair and insensitive to small business during hard economic times and that further job losses due to business closures would further impair the chances for a full economic recovery in Canada.
Therefore, your petitioners call upon Parliament to freeze unemployment insurance premium rates at the 1991 level for one year.

Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to table a petition signed by hundreds of residents of Hamilton, Ontario, Montreal and a number of cities in British Columbia. It notes that in February of 1985 the House of Commons asked the justice committee to prepare a report on equality rights in Canada and that the committee in October submitted a report unanimously recommending that the Canadian Human Rights Act be amended to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation in all areas of federal jurisdiction.

March 23, 1992

shared equally and fairly with police forces and local organizations so that they, who are on the leading edge in combating the drug abuse cancer that is spreading across Canada, will be able to fight this and fight it successfully.

I have the honour to present two petitions today.
