subsubtopic: MOTION TO ADJOURN UNDER S. O. 52 TRUDEAU GOVERNMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise under the provisions of Standing Order 52 to seek the adjournment of the House to debate an urgent issue of national importance. I would just like to take a moment to give my reasons.
The revelations of the last few days regarding Liberal cabinet authorization to violate the laws of Canada constitutes an urgent issue of national importance. Documents released under federal access law confirm that the Trudeau cabinet ordered the RCM Police to obtain Parti Quebecois documents, including membership lists, clearly contrary to the laws of Canada as passed by this Parliament.
The protection of democratic institutions is the ultimate responsibility of every member elected to this
place. If we were to allow these revelations of cabinet endorsed burglary and theft to go unchallenged, there would be good reasons for Canadians to lose faith in the rule of law and to question our collective commitment to open, lawful government.
Yesterday the former Prime Minister, Mr. Pierre Trudeau stated only: "The record is there". Both the present and past Liberal leaders, the member for Vancouver Quadra and the present leader were in the cabinet when the decision was made. Surely during a Standing Order 52 debate, Canadians can learn from them why the cabinet chose to order the RCM Police to break the law and if there were other similar activities.
Unless there is a full debate on these matters, the ability of Parliament to craft laws and of this or any future government to administer them will be injured.
The released documents also implicate persons such as Gordon Robertson, Secretary to the Privy Council and cut to the quick of the reliability of the conclusions reached by the McDonald royal commission into the RCM Police dirty tricks operations of the early 1970s.
Democratic institutions are fragile. It is surely urgent that this matter be fully aired today because, as we learned, Question Period and some other options ordinarily available for the airing of an issue such as this may not be the most appropriate. The options under Standing Order 52 seem to me to be the most appropriate to allow Canadians to know what truly took place.

I thank the hon. member and I thank him for giving me notice of this in advance, which gave me a chance to consider it.
First of all, and I say this to all hon. members and especially to the public that may be listening or watching, this is a matter which was of very grave concern to this country for a long period of time. There are members in the House, myself included, who were here when the matter was a subject of debate and then later the matter of the McDonald commission to which the hon. member has referred. However, I still have to apply the rules and while the matter may be important, and I accept the hon. member's concern which I am sure will be shared by others, I do not find that it would be appropriate, at least at the moment, to order an emergency debate.
March 23, 1992

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I was saying before Question Period, when the Minister of Finance tells us that he reduces the tax burden of the Canadian people, it is a delusion. The fact of the matter is that, in 1986, 19.9 per cent of each dollar earned went to taxes, while today 22.3 per cent of it goes to taxes, and that is excluding the GST. Just imagine how much higher this figure would be if we were to include the GST!
It is no wonder that the Canadian people are suspicious when the Minister of Finance comes and tells us that he intends to go in the same direction as his predecessor, because we know what the policies of the former Minister of Finance were that have plunged us in this economic slump. Repeated tax hikes, the GST, the US free trade deal, a ridiculous monetary policy and cuts in transfer payments to the provinces are responsible for the slump this country is in today.
As I said at the beginning of my speech, Mr. Speaker, a survey shows-and I will repeat it-that only 23 per cent of Canadians believe that this budget will help the Canadian economy.
How many times have you heard people say that this government's monetary policy is ridiculous? We, in the opposition, are not alone in saying so. Practically all national organizations in Canada and in Quebec, including the Conseil du Patronat, the Manufacturers' Association and the Chamber of Commerce, every one agrees that a high dollar does not help. And, of course, high interest rates definitely did not help the Canadian pulp and paper industry.
Government Orders
We have repeatedly asked this government for many months now to change this monetary policy which is at the root of this recession.In excess of 65 per cent of our exports are shipped across the border to the United States. When our dollar is high, we are not as competitive with the United States, we export less and, as a result, we have fewer jobs and our workers work less.
The government's negligence in terms of its monetary policy is destroying the pulp and paper industry, at a time when the industry is already weakened by the recession and the FTA with the United States.
Canadians want no part of these disastrous economic policies. The government proposes to keep increases in CMHC spending on social housing down to an annual average of 3 per cent. The government hopes to save $622 million during the next five years, and here again, the middle class will be the one to suffer.
As far as housing is concerned-I raised this matter during Oral Question Period a few weeks ago-we are faced with a dramatic situation in Montreal. People need low cost housing, and now this area is going to be cut back. What are we going to tell those people? There are endless waiting lists. Every day, every time we are in our riding offices, we meet people who are looking for low-cost housing, and the Minister of Finance turns around and provides nothing of the kind. We are not the only ones to say this. According to the head of the Federation des cooperatives d'habitation de Vile de Montreal, Mrs. Monique Blanchet, the federal government's withdrawal from this sector-and I am referring to co-operative housing-will mean that 500 new co-op units will not be built, despite 10,000 applications. Because the government withdrew from co-operative housing, 500 units can't be built this year, despite the fact that 10,000 people are on the waiting list. The situation is serious, and the ministers and the Conservative government have not done a thing. In fact they cut the few resources left in this area.
Low income groups are not the only ones to be hit by the government. Students have also suffered as a result of the Conservative budget. The government says students are an abiding concern, but you would hardly notice that from this budget. Ironically I received a letter

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
from a young student in my riding who deplored the fact that we invest very little in our educational institutions, colleges and universities. If we want to be competitive, that is where we should invest.
Earlier during Question Period, I heard the Minister of Transport bragging that CN had awarded a contract in the United States, when it could have avoided the political fallout by awarding a contract that would have provided jobs in Canada. Meanwhile the government is slashing funding for students, in other words slashing our future. Young people are the future of this country.
If we look at all the countries in the world that invest significantly in their institutions and educational system like Germany, Japan and so many other countries, we see that they are competitive and can compete in this increasingly global environment. But we are doing the opposite.
The government must change direction. If we continue, I have the impression that in the time the government has left, because I know it does not have much time. According to custom, there should be an election this fall, but according to the Constitution, they could continue to govern until the fall of 1993. But if we continue with these policies until the fall of 1993,1 think that it will be too late and it will take many years to restore the confidence of our consumers, young people and investors and to continue to give hope and keep this country great.
As Opposition Whip, I do not want to give the impression that I am criticizing only the government. When I see newspaper articles like the one of Wednesday, January 15 in La Presse, which said that Montreal is getting steadily poorer, I find that incredible. It says that manufacturing employment in Montreal declined 28 per cent in two years, between the summer of 1989 and the summer of 1991. The Conservative government was in power then. Of the 66,000 jobs lost, three-quarters disappeared in the first year, even before the recession really hit.
Another article in La Presse said that one out of two adults in Montreal does not work. That is serious: one in two adults. How can we go on? In this great beautiful city of Montreal, which was the pride of all Canadians and all
Quebecers, how come one adult in two does not work? That is totally unacceptable.
Another article in La Presse of March 7, 1992 said that thousands of full-time jobs are disappearing. If full-time jobs are disappearing by the thousand, how will we be able to revive our economy? How will we be able to put people back to work? It is not the Official Opposition but rather journalists and economists writing in national newspapers who are saying that.
On the editorial page of La Presse for March 7, 1992, Alain Dubuc, who is a well-known journalist and economist, headlined his article "Economy Assassinated". What a title: "Economy Assassinated". That is where we are at after just seven and a half years with this government. As I said earlier, this government should either change the economic policy that has resulted in this disastrous situation or it should call an election to let the people of Canada pick a government that would give them new hope.
I see that I have hardly a minute left. In closing, then, I would like to say that this government economic policy is truly appalling. As we go down a commercial street in our ridings, every weekend, we can see the for sale or for rent signs in store windows. The showcases are empty. The office towers are empty. It is really depressing. If it is depressing for us who are there only on the weekend, imagine how depressing it must be for the people who live there.
I hope that the Minister of Finance, the Prime Minister and the rest of cabinet, as well as all other Conservative members, will insist at their next caucus meeting that these disastrous economic policies be changed.

Mr. Speaker, I want to say to my colleague from Montreal that the condition he describes in his community is exactly the same in my community in downtown Toronto.
People are in deep economic pain in this country. There is a very high level of insecurity, and people in all
March 23, 1992

regions of this country are looking to this Chamber for some direction, for some hope.

Does my colleague from Montreal not share the view that entrepreneurship and retraining are things to which this government has really not given the proper respect or the proper support in terms of using them as catalysts to get people back to work?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank my hon. colleague for giving me the opportunity to continue to say what I was saying.
I agree with him 100 per cent that this government, in seven and a half years, has been paying lip service to entrepreneurship, to small business.
Two, three or four months before the last election, this government came with all the fanfare and announced a big program: the institute of entrepreneurship. Three and a half years after the election, where is the institute? Nobody knows where it is and nobody knows what it is doing.
My hon. colleague said that there are 1.7 million enterprises in this country. If we would encourage them to create a job each, we would have no unemployment in this country. That is the policy we need.
Government Orders
In the budget we saw the government trying to increase the ceiling of small business loans from $100,000 to $150,000 or $200,000. When I was small business critic I said the economy was good and businesses could use the high ceiling. The government said no.
Now there is no economic growth. Increasing the ceiling to $200,000 will not work because the bank will not give them a penny. What is the use? The government wants to look good.
The government looks good when it increases the ceiling from $100,000 to $200,000 so that the businesses can create business. There is no business.
I said in my closing remarks that when you walk on a commercial street, it is very discouraging. In every store, the windows are empty. There are only two types of signs: "For Rent" or "For Sale". There is no activity. What is the use of increasing the ceiling of the small business loans when there is no small business? There is no need to borrow.
Even if somebody had some ideas, the banks need so much collateral that they will not give a penny. I agree with my colleague that this government only gives lip service to small and medium sized business. When it comes to its friends, big business, then it is open. Today we saw an example during Question Period.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am happy to be able to participate in the debate this afternoon on the borrowing authority.
The borrowing authority is the central, paramount tool that the Government of Canada utilizes in terms of its government expenditures. The borrowing authority is central to the budgetary statements of the Government of Canada, and it is a central issue in terms of the confidence that the government places with regard to running the affairs of our country.
We have seen, over the last number of months, a number of initiatives which have been funded by the Government of Canada which have drawn some serious concerns from Canadians. Some have been in relation to the funding of the prosperity initiative which, by itself, one could argue intellectually is a wonderful concept and we should pursue it. As we have seen on the floor of the House of Commons, with interchanges with government representatives as well as members of the opposition, the government really does not know where it is going on that particular issue, but it is prepared to spend a fair

It has been in power for close to eight years. To embark upon this particular initiative at a fairly substantial cost to the taxpayers of this country is something one has to question in terms of the seriousness and the genuineness of this government in view of the fact that we are probably going to be facing a federal election within the next twelve months.
Some have said that perhaps these consultations are a prelude to the federal election which is to come in order for the government to consult with its friends in the private sector in order to ascertain its ideas in trying to put together a platform for the purposes of the next election.

The government has also announced in its budget something which is dear to my constituents and something that I find somewhat alarming in view of the stage we are at in Canadian economy. It is intending, as it has announced in the budget, to privatize the Cape Breton Development Corporation.
For those in the Chamber and those who may be viewing our proceedings here this afternoon, the Cape Breton Development Corporation was bom in 1967-68. The premier of the day, the former leader of the Conservative Party, the Hon. Robert Stanfield, is a great Nova Scotian. He has served this country with great distinction on the floor of the House of Commons. He was the premier of our province and he and a young minister of the Crown at that time, Allan MacEachen, came together and discussed what could be done because numerous coal mines in Cape Breton were being done away with by the private sector; they walked away. They took the key out and just said: "To hell with the community".
Federally we conceived and implemented what is known as the Cape Breton Development Corporation to try to assist the diversification of the local economy and also, in later years, to try to provide alternatives for the uses of coal in Cape Breton. If one were to look at the bottom line of this Crown corporation, one could not be as positive as one would want to be.

The minister responsible for Devco is in the House. The policy of Robert Stanfield, as premier of the province of Nova Scotia, was affirmed by his successor, the late G. I. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to say a few words on the borrowing bill before the House today. It is a bill of importance in terms of how the government sets its priorities.
I want to make remarks in a couple of areas. I want to express my concern about what is happening to the country in general. I think Canadians are feeling a general sense that our country is drifting away from us, that we do not have a sense of priorities as a people, as a Parliament since the government across the way is missing in a certain amount of leadership in terms of where it wants to bring this country.
The second part in this is a concern about what is happening to the farm economy in prairie Canada where farmer after farmer is being forced to leave the land through circumstances that are not her fault or his fault in any way whatsoever.
I will start off with the farm economy. In a recent tour of my riding, I had a chance to go to 10 different communities to have public meetings in those communities. I heard from person after person the difficulties they are facing on the farm today in terms of a decent and fair price.
The important thing is that they are not getting a fair price for their products. The important thing to know is that the farmers, relatively speaking, are getting less today than they got in the 1930s for a bushel of grain or for many of the other products that they ship and sell to the marketplace. When that happens, of course, the farmers are going to leave the land. There will be more and more bankruptcies, more and more hardship, leading to social problems for the farmer and the farmer's family. The small towns and villages will gradually lose population, lose businesses, have schools close down, have post offices close down. When that happens, people leave and the thing tends to snowball and more and more. Farm implement dealers leave. Automobile dealerships leave. More and more businesses leave and as a result, we find more and more rural depopulation over the entire prairies.
Veiy simply put, that is the situation on the prairies today. We are seeing a rapid depopulation of rural Canada, people moving to the towns and the cities, moving in particular outside of rural Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Alberta to the larger cities or off to British Columbia or, indeed, to the province of Ontario.
March 23, 1992

What is going to happen to the rural society and the rural fabric? What I find is that we have to do two or three things. First of all, the most important thing is that the farmer needs a fair price for the product that the farmer sells in the marketplace. The farmer needs to see some reflection of that price in the cost of producing that bushel of wheat, that pound of beef or that pound of pork he puts on the market. The farmer also needs a return that reflects a decent wage for himself or for herself in producing that farm product. The farmer needs a price that reflects parity between the input costs and a decent wage and what he or she receives from the marketplace. That is not happening today. That is not happening today despite the GRIP and NISA programs, despite the other programs that are in place at both the federal and provincial level.
What we need is a new farm program. We might call it a fair prices program or fair prices bill that will guarantee the farmer a return based on the cost of production.
The second thing that one notices immediately is that our farmers are caught now in a price war, in a trade war, between the Europeans and the Americans. There is a subsidy on grain for export from Europe and the United States to other countries in the world. It is the Canadian farmer who is caught in the middle of this price war and it is the Canadian farmer who is suffering the consequences of that particular war.
Our government has to be more aggressive in putting forward the arguments of our country around the world because it is our farmers and the Australians and the Argentinians and the New Zealanders who are caught in the crossfire of a vicious trade war between the Americans and the Europeans. If it does not stop soon, we are going to see even more farmers leave the land.
The third problem is the problems of the GATT negotiations as it effects the four national supply management marketing boards, the dairy commission, the turkey marketing agency, the chicken marketing board and the Canadian Egg Marketing Agency. Under article XI of the GATT, there is protection for our four national supply management boards.
What is happening now in the GATT negotiations is that the tendency or the momentum is to take away that protection from Canada, from our farmers. If we lose those marketing boards we in effect are going to lose those industries, because without the protection of the
Government Orders
supply marketing system the dairy farmer will not survive.
I remember about a month ago when the dairy farmers came to Ottawa. They had a huge demonstration here on Parliament Hill with 25,000 to 35,000 farmers from across the country. I remember the Stillborn family from my riding saying to me in my office: "If the dairy commission goes, it is not long before the dairy farmers go because these huge farm factories in the United States that produce milk will soon be shipping milk into Canada in huge tanker trucks at a lower price that can be produced in this country and undercutting the farmers who produce milk today". We have all kinds of additional costs in this country that you do not have in the United States.
We have the cost of a much more severe climate in this country than they have in parts of the United States. We have social programs which are, of course, expensive to keep in this country so our taxation regime is different than the United States. Without supply management, without the marketing boards, we are going to lose the dairy, chicken, turkey and egg farmers we have now .
I would like to see our Prime Minister take a much stronger stand on behalf of our farmers. I would like to see him fly to Washington, along with a delegation of Canadian farm leaders, and lobby the President of the United States on the position and the point of view of the Canadian farm.
Our problem is that President Bush and the American administration are the main ones pushing to get rid of the Canadian marketing boards so that there would be a greater market for the American farmers in this country.
If you have a market in this country of 26 million or 27 million people and the United States is south of the border, they are looking at that market and they are sort of savouring the market like a fox savours the chicken coop. They want to get inside the chicken coop and they want to feast on it.
Yet we do not see our Prime Minister going to Washington and saying to Mr. Bush: "Look. We have a democratic right to keep our marketing boards. We want to produce for our own market. We are competent and efficient. Our marketing boards are good for the farmers and good for the consumers. Our marketing boards in addition to that mean there are more jobs for the people of this country".

Government Orders
I go back to the Stillborn family from my riding. They explained that not only will we lose the farms if we lose the marketing boards, but we will lose all the jobs, the part-time help of people working on those dairy farms and working on those poultry farms and working on the egg producing farms. Many young people work part time on those jobs. We also lose the full-time jobs that go along with it.
In the city of Yorkton that I represent for example we have the Co-op Dairies which employs a lot of men and women in the dairy producing the milk products that go around our province of Saskatchewan. If we lose the marketing boards, how long will it be before we lose the dairies because if we start using American raw milk we are soon going to be using American cheese, American yogurt, American ice cream and other American products. The same thing is true of course in the chicken, turkey and egg industry as well.
We are looking here at losing the farmer, at losing tens of thousands of jobs for people in the small towns and the cities right across this country. Of course we are losing a stable and reliable market for the consumers of Canada.
Those are some of the problems facing the Canadian farmer today. The important thing is a fair price based on the cost of production. The other important thing is to have a Prime Minister that supports us in the GATT negotiations by going to Washington with the farm leaders and bringing opposition members of Parliament with him to make the case to the President of the United States, to Congress, to the American people why we as Canadians need to keep our marketing boards.
We need a government that is more effective and more outspoken about ending the trade war, the grain wars between the United States and Europe. Those are the three big issues that are facing farmers today.
There is a fourth very important issue and that is the issue of farm debt. Farm debt is there largely because of the problems of farm income. If we look at debt today we find that our farmers are in greater debt than they have been for decades in this country. Many farmers are being forced to leave the land. There is farm bankruptcy after farm bankruptcy.
I know of a couple of cases in my riding where the farm stress situation because of debt have led to some very serious problems. People have contemplated suicide
because of the stress on the family, because of what it has done to the children of those particular families that all of a sudden come from a household that does not have the money to buy the basic necessities of life, let alone some of the things that most children want and need for their own development, their own entertainment.
These are the social consequences that are facing rural Canada today. One of the problems we have of course is that in the rural communities people live a long way apart. They live on farms scattered throughout many miles. They live in small villages and on small farms so that we do not see in a vivid and explicit way many of the problems that we tend to see in urban Canada, such as food banks, soup kitchens, people living on the streets, the homeless and people living in small homes, small apartments on minimum wage or people begging on the streets. We see that in urban Canada. In rural Canada much of that poverty, suffering and misery are hidden from public view. But I assure you, Mr. Speaker, it is there.
I conclude this part of my remarks by saying that the most important industry, the fundamental number one industry in this country is the agricultural industry. If we have a strong farming base, and of course fishing and forestry in other parts of the country, in other words the renewable primary industries, we will build a strong country and create jobs for Canadians from one coast to the other.
I do not see that vision today. I do not see that plan today. I do not see that objective today in terms of the government's spending priorities either in the budget or in the borrowing bill in terms of what it wants to borrow money for.
The other point I want to make is that as I travel around this country I feel that Canadians are fearing for Canada. They are wondering what is going to happen to this country of ours. It is not only the farm crisis. There is the unemployment crisis. People are being thrown out of work. There is a recession that is worse than the recession back in the early 1980s, 1981-83. We have a recession that has caused hardship, because we had high interest rates, because we have an overinflated dollar, because we have a trade deal that was signed between this government and the United States which I maintain has given away too much of our sovereignty. The trade
March 23, 1992

deal should be scrapped and should never have been signed in the first place.
That trade deal is hurting this country. In particular, it is hurting manufacturing. We are seeing that in the province of Ontario and it is hurting every single province of this country. Yet we have a government that is now negotiating not just a trade deal between us and the United States but trying to expand that trade deal to include the Mexicans as well. That concerns me when I see the wage rates in Mexico compared to Canada where people are paid one to three dollars an hour compared to $14, $15, $16 an hour here. In Mexico they have no social benefits compared to social benefits in this country, they have little or no environmental regulations or standards compared to what we have today.
When I see those comparisons, when I see those differences I fear for the Canada that we are going to have if this government signs the trade deal with Mexico.
I think Canadians are fearing for their country. They are fearing that their national institutions are slipping away, that CBC is slipping away, the post office, the railway system and the airlines. Canadians say to me now from coast to coast that we want our country back. We want this country back. We want Canada back once again.

We need a country that is stronger and sounder than it is now. We have many economic problems. I mentioned the high rate of unemployment, farmers, the problems we find throughout the country, and the problems we have as a result of the FTA between our country and the United States. We also have to deal with national unity and the Constitution, to achieve unity between Quebec and Canadians across this country.

It is important that we have a national vision, that we have a national dream, that we start building once again, that we start spending our money in this country on research and development, on education so that we can create jobs. In the long run, I do not think it is any secret on how to create jobs in this country. If you look at Japan, western Europe, parts in the United States and
Government Orders
other parts of the world, many of them having fewer resources than us, what they basically do are three things for making their economies more competitive and more efficient. They invest in training. They invest in education and they invest in research and development.
What do we do? We do not invest anywhere nearly as much in those areas as most countries around the world. In research and development, our investment per capita is at roughly the same level as the Republic of Ireland or the country of Egypt. Is it any wonder we in this country are falling further and further behind our neighbours in Europe, the United States and Japan? We do not have the national priority and the national vision to do what other countries have done so well.
Mr. Speaker, 50 years ago, Japan was crushed by nuclear bombs during the Second World War. France was also crushed, like so many European countries. And today, the standard of living in many European countries is as high as it is in Canada or even higher, in some cases, and we see the same phenomenon in Japan.
If people in Japan, France, Germany, Sweden, Switzerland, and many other European countries have a national vision, we could also have a national vision in this country.

We can do many things in this country. We can educate our people. We can train our people. We can put our people to work on building a strong and independent Canada that can be competitive and efficient and compete with anybody anywhere in the world, but we can only do that if we have a national dream and a national objective and a national motivation to do that. I sense that the government across the way does not have that any more, if indeed it ever did.
The last point is that the people of this country are afraid of losing our social programs. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today we are considering Bill C-61, which deals with our country's economic issues, with the broad economic issues of the day. First of all, I would like to say that as Canadians we all know that we have quite a few economic problems. Instead of getting better, the situation is getting worse every day.
We know that the unemployment rate recently went up to 10.6 per cent, which means we are not coming out of the recession but are still right in the middle of one. Canadians are afraid of what will happen to the economy in the future, and that is why retail sales have not picked up. Canadians are afraid of losing their jobs.
However, this is a direct result of the government's policies. Two years ago the government started with its high dollar and high interest rate policy. According to them it was the only way to make Canada more competitive. As a result, we now have a made-in-Canada recession, created by the policies of this government.

Our recession in Canada started long before the American recession because it was a made-in-Canada recession. What have we seen today?
In my city of Toronto, the unemployment rate is about
10.5	per cent. There are 211,000 Torontonians looking for work and cannot find it. Every person in this House, from whatever party, knows what it is like when a
March 23, 1992

constituent who is 40 or 50 years of age comes into your office and says: "You are my last hope. I have lost my job. My unemployment insurance has run out. I have sold my car. I have sold my house. Now I am losing my family".
Do we not have a responsibility to those individuals? Do we not realize that more than any other group in this country we are responsible for the tragic plight of these people who face unemployment? We cannot give them hope in terms of saying their jobs are going to come back. So many jobs are not going to come back.
Canada, in the three years since free trade, has lost
345,000	manufacturing jobs. That is 16 per cent of all our manufacturing jobs. Those are the highest paying jobs. They are not lay-offs, they are permanent job losses. The companies have closed up, and in many cases the jobs have gone south of the border.
Look at the auto industry. The auto industry is probably the key to whatever we are going to do in NAFTA. Canada has lost, since free trade came in, three short years, 21,213 auto jobs. That is 21 per cent of our auto jobs. When I asked the government the other day what it intends to do about it, it said that things are rosy and that the United States is losing jobs as well.
The United States, in those same three years, has lost just 9 per cent of its auto jobs. We are losing our automotive jobs at two and a third times the U.S. rate. This is due in large measure to an ill-conceived free trade deal that wiped out the safeguards for auto jobs in Canada. That is why we are losing the jobs much more quickly and they are going south of the border. Things are not well because we are going to continue losing more of those jobs unless this government shows some leadership and is prepared to step in and say: "Enough is enough. We are going to stand up for Canadian workers".
The member for London East raised the issue today of General Motors. It lost a deal at its London plant for 25 locomotives. Who is going to pick up those 25 locomotives and create the jobs? General Electric in the United States is going to.
Government Orders
CN is buying these locomotives. CN has public funding. It is a Crown corporation. Can you imagine anything more stupid than our Crown corporations helping American workers?
We heard the member for York South-Weston who showed how we had increased funding from $.6 million to $17 million for Canadian studies abroad. At the same time here in Canada we are cutting out the Science Council, the Economic Council. At the same time this government is spending $21.2 billion on an ill-conceived prosperity agenda. This prosperity agenda asks stupid questions to which we already know the answers, questions it raised in its 1984 mini budget. What has it been doing? Eight lost years and it did not even answer them.
In effect, Canadians have answered. We have a high pile of studies telling the government what should be done in the area of education, training, research and development, science, technology, innovation, financing entrepreneurs. These studies have done at public expense already. Why did it not read these to get the answers? It had to spend $21.2 billion so it can consult with Canadians. Canadians do not need this consultation. The answers are there.
The government is being political. It is spending over $3 million to simply advertise these meetings. Thirty or forty people are invited by paid consultants to come to these meetings and listen to some of the things the government has to say. The answers are already there. We know this is a government that is not prepared to consult and listen. It is prepared to advertise and tell Canadians what it wants, but it is not a government that is prepared to listen.
Did it listen to big business or exporters about the crushing impact of the high dollar and high interest rates on exports and on jobs in Canada and on the cost of the deficit? Did it listen to small business in terms of its two unemployment insurance premium increases? Why are labour and small business not part of this on-going prosperity agenda consultation process?
This government played fast and free with its own public servants when it limited them to 0 and 3 per cent increases at the same time that it was giving senior officials huge increases, at the same time that was giving

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
the Bank of Canada 6 per cent increases. How stupid. Labour had to back out of this prosperity agenda.
In Canada we all know that if we are going to get our economy turned around, one of the keys has to be that labour and management and governments at all levels must learn to work together. They do in other countries. Canada has the worst record of labour strife and days lost of any country in the OECD. How are we going to get competitive unless we work together for a common purpose? Instead of enhancing that co-operative spirit, the government has been destroying it repeatedly.
What did it do in this budget, which came down about a month ago, to try to remedy the situation? What did it do about this rising unemployment? I will give the government credit on two counts. It accepted the advice that we have been giving it for several years now, consistently, saying that the housing sector is one of the most important sectors in Canada for creating new jobs. We had recommended lowering the down payments and using other possibilities such as pension funds and RRSPs for funding the down payment on homes.
We know that if we can get the 50 per cent of our construction workers who are not working today back on the jobs, we are going to have not only housing, but immediate creation of jobs, if the government accepted these two proposals.
Those proposals did not cost any money. The government was not prepared to go further, as we suggested, in dealing with the municipal infrastructure programs in which we have to build new sewers to look after our environment and stop pollution. All we wanted to do was prepay a couple of those schemes that were on municipal books, to bring them forward a little bit. Was this government prepared to enter into a co-operative program with the provinces and municipalities in itself? Was it prepared to spend, in advance, a little bit of money to create these necessary infrastructures and also get people back to work, giving people the dignity of a job? The best social program is a job, it is not welfare that is augmented and is being paid for by the municipalities at the same time as this government is cutting back its payments for education.
At the same time, from the 1986-87 year until the 1992-93 fiscal year, this government has cut back its
transfers to the provinces by $4.9 billion. There has been a $4.9 billion decrease over what it had committed to spend before.
With this type of approach, there is no doubt this is a government that is not prepared to create jobs to arrest this rising unemployment. This government was not prepared in its budget to accept our proposal for more basic training. This government was not prepared to even put $25 million to help with the food banks.
Today, there are two million Canadians using food banks regularly. Seven hundred thousand of those are children and the food banks are stretched-what a travesty in a country that has so much. We have come to rely on them. We have to get these Canadians back to work to give them the training and the education. We have to get the science and technology going.
We know that innovation, entrepreneurship, science and technology and research and development are the keys to the future. What has this government done? The Prime Minister promised everyone of us in this House and all Canadians in 1984 that he was going to double R and D by 1988. It has gone down. It has gone down below the level it was at in 1984. We are now down to the level which is less than half of that of our major OECD competitors.
Where are our young scientists who are going to universities going to get the jobs? The government will say it is the fault of the private sector. Blame it on the private sector, blame everything on somebody else, but the fact is that this is a government that admitted to Canadians that with the high degree of foreign ownership and multinational corporations in Canada, the R and D is just not going to get done here in the private sector. The minister of industry said a couple of years ago that branch plants just do not do R and D. What did this government do in its last budget? It decreased the withholding taxes on payments to foreign multinationals as if this is going to get them to come in here and do an R and D. Was it linked to more funding by these branch plants for R and D? Was it linked to the creation of more jobs in Canada? What a boon to have your withholding tax rate cut in half cut in half when you are sitting with profits and you want to repatriate them to your own home country.
March 23, 1992

If you are going to get at the problem, that is not the way to do it. We face a real crisis in terms of retaining our jobs and creating them here in Canada. The government is now engaged in the North American free trade agreement negotiations, NAFTA. It has a great deal of hope for these agreements. It said: "We are going into NAFTA and we are going to become part of NAFTA". There are no conditions, no qualifiers. It is an article of faith that free trade with anyone is good. There are not even ant terms.
We have suggested to this government to take our auto sector, which will and must be a deal breaker for NAFTA.
As I have said before, we have lost 21 per cent of our auto jobs under the free trade agreement at a rate two and one-third times the U.S. job loss rate for auto workers.
Are we prepared to stand up for Canada's needs or are we simply ideologues, free trade, marketplace, all those things are to the benefit of us all the time. We have a chance to say that we want a fair deal for Canadian workers. We want Canada to have its fair share of auto jobs.
Every expert recognizes the auto pact lead to the establishment of a high-level automobile industry, a world-competitive automobile industry in Canada going back to 1965. That auto pact basically said: "You will have free trade in North American automobiles, but only if you produce an equivalent number of vehicles in Canada. You can bring one vehicle into Canada duty free if you produce one vehicle in Canada". That is fine. We used our market to guarantee certain jobs. You get our market free, but you have got to produce jobs here.
That safeguard for jobs was wiped out by the free trade agreement. It was wiped out to the point that by 1998, when all the tariffs are gone, the Big Three could pull all their production out of Canada, there could be no auto parts jobs here, they could ship cars into Canada from the United States duty free and not have one job here in Canada.
The Conservatives believe that free trade is a necessary part of globalization. That is naivety of the worst order. What percentage of Japan's auto market is served by foreign auto manufacturers? Three per cent. In the European Community they are debating whether by the
Government Orders
year 2000 they will allow foreign penetration to go to either 15 per cent or 17 per cent.
Today in Canada the European, Japanese and Korean auto-makers, the foreign auto-makers, have 37 per cent of our market and produce only 3 per cent of the auto jobs in Canada. Now to me, that is being the Boy Scouts, naive to the nth degree, and we are the ones who suffer for not standing up for our rights, the rights of our workers to use our market to create a fair share of Canadian jobs. Why give it away for nothing? The other countries do not do it. The other countries are not practising free trade. Why should we be the only ones to do it?
In these NAFTA agreements, we have asked the government some very specific questions and we have asked it for some terms and conditions. We want, first of all, a North American tariff level or quota level which is going to get foreign penetration of the North American market back down to international norms. Why should we be higher than our major competitor, the European Community or Japan? Is that asking too much? Is it really?
Second, we want to go back to something like the auto pact. Not only will we give free trade within North America, but we want to make sure that free trade applies in a way that Canadian jobs are not sacrificed. So that means that we have to undo the provisions of the free trade agreement that allow these manufacturers to pull completely out of Canada. As a price for coming into Canada free of duty they should be prepared to create some jobs here. This is what we are asking, that is all.
We are going to have to have not only North American content rules, but country or Canadian content rules if we are going to get back to where we should be in terms of international norms and in terms of Canada's fair share of North American auto jobs. Let us not be the only naive people.
There is a lot of misunderstanding going on with this government. There is a canard out there promoted by this government, that the dispute settlement mechanism under the free trade agreement has just been a wonderful boon for Canadians.
We now have the Honda decision. They can impose tariffs on us and the only right we have is to consult with the Americans about these tariffs they have imposed on us and then after consultations go to a panel. But that panel's decision will not be binding on the United States

unless the United States agrees. There is no binding arbitration of the Honda dispute. This is the most potentially damaging decision that has ever been taken to Canada's industrial future. It means that no other country or no other corporation within Canada or outside is going to establish in Canada to service the North American market.
We have got so much to do. I wish I could speak longer.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to direct a question to my colleague from Willowdale. He has given a very succinct speech. He has an appreciation of all the problems that this country is confronted with. In my particular area I do not think there is one area in which it is illustrated so clearly the mistaken policies of this government as in the crossborder shopping issue.
I live in a border town. I can look across the water and see the United States. I see the devastating effect that cross-border shopping has had on the merchants in these small towns along the St. Lawrence, which is my beat.
I was suggesting to the government, because this has been tried, this is not a stab in the dark. It was tried in one community where they lowered the price of gasoline by giving out coupons. The merchants gave out coupons and lowered the price of gasoline. They found the biggest single attraction to the United States is the price of fuel. Fuel is not a luxury. Most householders, working men and women, have a car and they need that. At one time perhaps fuel was a luxury. It is not now.
I am convinced that if this government would make some kind of a study to determine the amount of revenue generated from the 8.5 cents federal excise tax on fuel, and if it would drop that, drop it totally or reduce it drastically, that it would turn around the economy of these small centres.
When people go to the United States to fill their gas tanks with fuel, while they are there they shop. That seems to me like a rather simple sort of solution to the problem. Take away the attraction. I do not blame the people. I never blamed the Canadian people for going to the United States to shop. With the policies of this government, it is driving them to the United States to shop.
I just wondered if my friend from Willowdale would like to comment on that kind of perception. It is not imagined; it is real. All you have to do is drive through these towns and see the number of shops that were thriving a few years ago. They are closed now. The first challenge of the minister was to do something to stimulate the economy, to get the economy moving again, and to do something in the short term to bring down this appalling level of unemployment.
The second challenge the Minister of Finance faced was to formulate and to implement measures that would restructure the Canadian economy and would halt the decline in our country's level of competitiveness and productivity which has been eroded seriously during the mandate of this government.
We realized that the Minister of Finance did not have a lot of fiscal room in which to manoeuvre. There was no

opportunity to make lavish increases in spending and in new programs that would be very costly for Canadian taxpayers. However, the Minister of Finance had an opportunity and a responsibility to deal with these twin problems facing our economy.

First, Canadians were looking to this budget to provide some stimulus to get Canada's economy out of this recession. Canadians were not looking for wild and extravagant spending that would indebt the government further. They had a right to expect the minister to give the inflation song a rest and begin to address the real problem in our economy, the 10.6 per cent of able-bodied Canadians who do not have work.
The Minister of Finance proclaimed in his budget a plan to cut spending and taxes in 1992-93 by $1 billion, as if this would solve all of our problems. Surely we know by now that this is not the case. This is little better than conventional wisdom and a timid version of what the government would have us believe is its fiscal policy.
Let us not forget that last year the government told us that through its program of fiscal restraint the deficit would fall below $25 billion in 1992-93. Nothing could be further from the truth. It has now modified its estimates, saying that the debt will be reduced to $27.5 billion. It begs the question, why should we believe it now?
What about the unemployed? Is the government contending that the measures announced in this budget will solve all of the problems by stimulating economic growth? I am sure that is what it would have us believe. Canadians have every right to be doubtful, especially as far as this government is concerned.
I noted in this year's estimates that an additional $1.6 billion will be required to pay for the administration and expenditures of unemployment insurance over last year. As put so bluntly in the government's estimates of 1992-93, the total projected UI expenditures of $20.3 billion reflect the anticipated impact of a continuing recession on unemployment levels.

March 23, 1992
Government Orders
In light of this statement, what has this government done to address the tragedy of unemployment in this country? It has done nothing, and that is the greatest tragedy of all.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate my colleague from Cape Breton Highlands-Canso on his speech on this borrowing bill.
The words he spoke here before the House showed clearly that this government lacks the ability to govern the Canadian people. It lacks in that it has no imagination. The borrowing authority bill is before the House for passage. At the same time, we have passed a budget that has provided absolutely nothing in the way of incentive to Canadians for growth. Nor do we see any vision that this government might have for Canadians to spur them on.
The leader of our party had an idea that this budget should be giving something to stimulate Canadians. He had this idea as a result of many trips across Canada and as a result of many visits by members of Parliament to their constituencies and other places.
I cannot believe we are here borrowing. We saw nothing to give a stimulus to the Canadians to get the economy moving. We saw no restraint except for the ministers' salaries being frozen. At the same time, we know that the civil service is in a wage range that far surpasses members of Parliament who are here to supposedly represent Canadians and bring suggestions to the House. The salaries of the nine top categories in the Public Service are higher, starting with the lowest to the highest, than those of members of Parliament.
In the United States there is a capping on that by saying that the public service in the United States cannot be paid higher than members of the Congress or of the Senate. We do not see that in Canada. We do not even see that initiative on the part of what I call a dead-end government speaking to a Public Service that is not coming up with the ideas, speaking to Crown corporations in this House whose salaries are on the advice of an advisory group to the cabinet.
Today in the House there were two or three questions on the direction of Canadian National Railways to go out and get a contract in the United States.
These Crown corporations and the Public Service are not stimulated with high salaries.
Canadian National Railways goes from about a recommended $317,000 to $396,000. It seems to me that somewhere this government should have talked about that restraint and not restraining the Economic Council of Canada or the Law Reform Commission, which are aids to a sagging government with very few new policy ideas.

Mr. Speaker, Canada's first co-operative housing program was introduced in 1973 under a Liberal government.
In 1986 this government promised to produce 5,000 units of co-op housing a year. This goal was never achieved. Instead, under a Conservative government the number of co-op units constructed has declined and funding for the program has been in jeopardy for the last two years.
Funding for the 1992 program was no different. After extensive lobbying the minister of state for housing announced on December 17, 1991 that the funding for co-op housing would be renewed with a budget of $6.1 million.

Adjournment Debate
As recently as February 19, less than a week before the budget was introduced in this House, the same minister confirmed in writing that the co-op housing budget was secure. Based on his assurances co-op housing groups across the country proceeded with the development of co-op proposals.
In an attempt to justify this broken promise the government is claiming that the co-op housing program is not targeted to those in need of affordable housing. On March 11, 1992, the Minister of Finance criticized the co-op housing program and I quote:
How is it that it is well targeted when 50 per cent of those who occupy these units are not in effect qualified under the provisions of social housing?
The minister is revealing his ignorance of the co-op housing program. He is correct when he states that 50 per cent of those who occupy co-op housing units are not qualified for social housing.
What he failed to acknowledge is that this same 50 per cent of occupants pay market rents for their co-ops. These units are not subsidized by the government. It is the other 50 per cent that the funding is targeted to.
This statement by the Minister of Finance also contradicts his own colleague, the Minister of State for Housing, who said in his December press release that the co-op housing program is targeted. I quote:
The revised program will make more effective use of scarce dollars ensuring federal subsidies are fully directed towards a mix of low- and moderate-income families.
These statements prove that while the government was praising that co-op housing program a few months ago, now the Minister of Finance is making excuses for eliminating the successful and cost effective program. It appears this government is willing to alter its conclusion of a program in order to justify its rash decisions.
In his March 11 comments the Minister of Finance also stated that the government had done enough to stimulate housing through its introduction of the RRSP for down payments and the 5 per cent down payment. While I applaud the government for introducing these two programs which I have personally been promoting for a year, I must note that these programs help those Canadians who have savings to purchase a home.
Co-ops meet the needs of a different segment of the Canadian population. By eliminating the co-op housing program this government is eliminating a valuable housing program for the lower and middle income families. It provides mixed income communities, not ghetto housing. The elimination of the co-op housing program will also cost 4,400 construction and manufacturing jobs this year alone, adding to the unemployment insurance expenditures.
This government has also progressively eliminated the federal role in housing through the budgetary process, not through the constitutional dialogue. The cancellation of the co-op housing program, a program that is very popular in many Canadian provinces is just another example of this. The termination of the co-op housing program is an abdication of this government's responsibility to provide adequate and affordable shelter to Canadians in a healthy community environment.
There are over 164,000 Canadians who are on a waiting list for co-op housing. Why is this government abandoning these Canadians? The program is cost effective and offers affordable housing and mixed income communities for seniors, single parents, natives, the disabled, and low-income earners.
Will this government keep its commitment to housing groups and provide the $6.1 million for new co-op housing commitments?

March 23, 1992

al households, we expect in the neighbourhood of 28,000 this year.
The federal government assists households in need, especially those in real targeted need across the country, through the social housing program. The government will continue to spend approximately $2 billion annually, which totals over $10 billion in the next five years.
With respect to the termination of the co-op index-linked mortgage program, the moderate income households, which are some of the clients that the program supports, now have more opportunities to access affordable, decent housing in the private market.

Mr. Speaker, on December 6, I asked the acting Minister of Employment and Immigration what was being done to meet the needs of immigrant women in violent situations.
She replied that there are already programs to integrate immigrant women into society. She did not seem to realize how inadequate these programs are in meeting the special needs of immigrant women to encourage them to assert their rights, to become independent and to escape violence.
The government showed its lack of concern for minority women when the recent budget rolled back pay equity in the Public Service, cancelled the Court Challenges Program, indefinitely deferred the Race Relations Foundation, changed the Foreign Domestic Program to exclude many women from developing countries and cut $100 million from the Canadian Jobs Strategy program.
There are few shelters specifically suited to assist immigrant women who need to escape violence. Shelters for mainstream women are inadequately funded with no resources for effective cross-cultural staff training.
Adjournment Debate
Violence against women, particularly against immigrant women, is a multi-faceted problem which requires specific government action. Immigrant women are doubly disadvantaged because of racism and sexism. They suffer abuse in silence because the discrimination in our society keeps them in unsafe and vulnerable situations.
Many immigrant women are sponsored by their husbands under the family class. In order to remain in Canada, their sponsorship must be intact. Therefore, many women who suffer violence in their homes are afraid to speak out or to seek help for fear of jeopardizing their immigration status. They cannot leave and are locked into violent situations and so are their children.
The co-chair of the Canadian Panel on Violence against Women, Pat Marshall, said: "Immigrant and visible minority women often have to leave their communities to escape violence and are cut off from their culture". This is not a realistic alternative for many women since their community is often the only support network they have in Canada.
Their lack of language skills also perpetuates the silence in violent situations. When they cannot speak English or French they are insecure and isolated and afraid to leave an abusive partner. The Minister of Employment and Immigration allocated $200 million to increase access to language training for immigrant women. However, this program excludes most immigrant women since it does not offer training allowances or child care. Immigrant women, like many other women in Canada who are primary caregivers in their households, often lack job opportunities and may not have any income of their own. Without training allowances, this government is offering only false hope for many women who continue to be isolated in violent situations.
The lack of professional accreditation for many immigrant women means that they cannot find employment commensurate with their training and experience.
In addition, this government has not implemented employment equity effectively with targets, timetables and penalties. The Canadian Jobs Strategy program was one of the few training resources available to immigrant women, women who want to enter or re-enter the job market.

March 23, 1992
Adjournment Debate
With this year's cuts, the government has decreased CJS training by 35 per cent for immigrant women. How can immigrant women escape violence in their homes when they cannot be independent economically and socially?
To end violence against women, we need to eliminate inequalities in every facet of our society. Government action is needed now because it is a matter of survival for many immigrant women and their families. Women who are victims of violence must have full protection and refuge from violent situations.

Mr. Speaker, I will face you this time.

My colleague from South Shore stood up in the House today and presented a petition signed by 14,793 people from the three counties in the southern end of Nova Scotia. Anyone who sails the waters offshore from our villages knows how important it is to have a search and rescue facility. It was important in the past year because 22 lives were saved because this search and rescue facility was in place in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia.
Yesterday there was-you would not say a demonstration- a meeting of 250 to 300 people who came out in bitter cold weather. On the platform along with myself and the member for South Shore, there were politicians from every level of government, municipal, provincial, including a minister from the provincial level.
The provincial minister and his colleague, Mr. Huskil-son from Shelburne were there along with the wardens from Yarmouth, Clare and Argyle. No one is saying that this is not an essential service. No one wants to see it go.
It may cost somebody a little bit of time to find the money that is needed to provide such an important service. It is not just for tourists who are perhaps boating or for other people who are using it, it is for our own fishermen who are out there daily in weather conditions that makes it sometimes incredible that they go out there.
I want to just reassure the House that this need is not a frivolous demand by the people in this area. The time is coming, April 1, when the contract will have expired. The minister that day said that an announcement would be given shortly. Speaking to the Minister of Fisheries
March 23, 1992

and Oceans during a committee last week, he said that the decision was imminent.

Mr. Speaker, on December 5, 1991 this House passed with a
Adjournment Debate
large majority Bill C-17, a bill to revise our gun laws and make them more effective.
Royal assent was given to the bill on that date, December 5, 1991. However, the bill has not in fact become law because regulations have not been tabled in the House and the bill has not been proclaimed law by Order in Council.
On December 6, I asked the minister when those regulations would be tabled and when the bill would be proclaimed. Unfortunately she did not give me an answer on that date.
Here it is now three and a half months later and we still do not have this important bill proclaimed and we still do not have the regulations tabled in this House.
The demand and the need for this law were to plug the weaknesses in the existing gun control legislation. That goes back to December 1989 when 14 young women were assassinated by a a single gunman at the Polytechnique Institute in Montreal.
Here I am again today, as I say three and a half months later, asking the government when this important law will be proclaimed and when the regulations will be tabled.
That law, Bill C-17, was not a perfect law but it introduced some very real and good improvements. For example, under that law it will now take 28 days for an applicant to get a firearms acquisition certificate. The delay will give time for the authorities, the police, to investigate the applicant and see if he is a trustworthy person. It also provides for two guarantors or co-signers on the application form.
It goes into other things such as safe storage of weapons and the requirement for a national training program for those who want to use weapons. Of course one of the major gaps in the law is that it did not cover the control of ammunition, and I regret that. But, as I say, what is there represents a very real improvement.
I understand that the delay rests in part with the Canadian Advisory Council on Firearms that is preparing recommendations for the minister with respect to the regulations. I simply want to say this: I hope the regulations that are being prepared by this advisory council are not going to circumvent the wishes of Parliament, because Parliament wanted an effective law.

March 23, 1992
Adjournment Debate
At the last Gallup poll on this matter in 1991,80 per cent of Canadians said they wanted tough gun laws. Parliament passed such a law last December. So let's get on with it.
I see the parliamentary secretary here. He served on the committee that heard representations on this matter. I hope he is here to give me some good news today, that he will give me a specific date when we will have this law proclaimed, when we will have the regulations in effect.

speakeroldname: Mr. Dave Worthy (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the minister shared the member's pleasure that the firearms control provisions in Bill C-17 received such strong support in the Senate when the bill was given royal assent last December. I am confident that the vast majority of Canadians share her view that this new legislation represents a major step toward enhancing public safety in Canada.
I want to assure all members that the Minister of Justice is most anxious the important regulatory and legislative provisions of this act are proclaimed into force at the earliest possible date.
There are, however, important considerations which must be taken into account before various measures can be implemented. Many millions of Canadians are affected. In order that their considerations are reflected, the advice of the Canadian Advisory Council on Firearms and other groups that have proposed views on this subject will be taken into account. And consultations have taken place with provincial and territorial attorneys general.
Another very important consideration is that we ensure adequate information, materials and strategies have been developed and put in place so that both criminal justice administrators and gun owners are properly informed and aware of the new requirements before they come into effect.
The hon. member has said that the regulations and the legislation must be effective. They also could be summed up in two other words: what is needed is that they be practical and workable.
The government is planning a phased in approach to proclamation dates respecting the firearms provisions. The Minister of Justice will be announcing the actual proclamation date at the earliest possible time.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, northern Ontario and many other regions in our country are suffering from very high rates of unemployment. Many of these regions have suffered these high rates of unemployment for some time now. As a result they have exhausted UI claims and must rely on social assistance.
In reply to a question I raised in this House on February 11, 1992, the Minister of Employment and Immigration stated: "We have in place programs worth $1.8 billion that allow for the training of the unemployed this year".
While I am aware that there are training programs for the unemployed, these programs do not serve the large numbers of recipients of social assistance. They serve only those who are presently collecting UI benefits. If a recipient of UI benefits applies and is accepted on one of these training programs, even though he has applied at the veiy end of his time to be receiving UI benefits, it matters not. Once he is accepted into this program, he will go on and receive UI benefits for the duration of the training program.
I have had occasion in my riding recently to be aware of people who missed that deadline by about one week. They had collected UI benefits, they applied for a program and they were accepted one week too late. So there is nothing for them. They cannot access the moneys and so they are totally out of it.
I am veiy interested in making sure that some of these people do have the training that is needed also for them because the person who did not qualify because he was accepted one week too late into the program is certainly just as much in need of retraining as the one previous. I want to say that all unemployed should enjoy the same access to retraining whether they receive social assistance or UI.
This government may state that allowing all access to retraining under the Unemployment Insurance Act would be too costly, and I would agree that we should be as cost effective as possible, but many agencies are trying and have tried to fill these gaps and help these social assistance recipients to access training. Unfortunately and unwisely in the face of the realities of this situation this government is cutting back dollars for this category of unemployed. I refer now to the cutbacks under the Canadian Jobs Strategy.
March 23, 1992

This makes me question the government's real commitment to training and retraining. I know of one group in particular which will have difficulty moving forward with a national employability project, a group which has a long history of helping the severely disadvantaged poor, namely the Salvation Army.
There are many reasons for the scarcity of dollars being directed to these severely employment disadvantaged. Not least is the cap on transfer payments to the provinces. This does not allow provinces adequate dollars to deal with the increased numbers of welfare recipients. The municipalities are in the same position. They in turn are faced with increased numbers of welfare recipients. They only have the poor, cash strapped property taxpayer and they are obligated to pay more to just offer the basic necessities of living, let alone retraining.
More training programs are urgently needed for this group across the country.
I ask the government, again, will it consider the issue of funding of employability training programs for those who do not qualify for unemployment insurance? Let us ensure that the growing number of social assistance recipients, casualties of this recession, are fully included in labour force development strategies.

speakeroldname: Mr. Dave Worthy (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank the hon. member. I know her concern is real and, like so many in the House, would like to see more dollars available for many of these programs.
On behalf of the Minister of Employment and Immigration Canada, I am pleased to outline some of the programs available to the unemployed.
Adjournment Debate
As the Minister of Employment and Immigration has already mentioned, in 1991-92 approximately $3 billion was made available to provide training and adjustment programs to Canadian workers and employers. In 1992-93, $3.4 billion, an increase of $300 million, has been, allocated for training and adjustment.
In 1991-92, Ontario will receive approximately $821 million in training and adjustment funds. It is expected that a good portion of these moneys will be spent in northern Ontario, in the area that she represents.
Under the Labour Force Development Strategy, which is Canada's blueprint for creating a highly and internationally competitive labour force, new programs have been designed to build on the strengths and successes of the Canadian Jobs Strategy.
Programs like the Employability Improvement Program, with options such as project based training or job opportunities, provide employers with assistance to hire selected candidates.
Last year, more than 600,000 Canadians in all walks of life and all regions, participated in our training and adjustment programs. In the coming year, we expect to help tens of thousands more.
